transcript:
Doctor: Hi there, can you tell me what brought you in today?
Patient: Yeah, I came in because I've been having a headache, feeling really tired, and I've got a fever too.
Doctor: I see. When did these symptoms start?
Patient: They started around midnight, back in June 2014.
Doctor: Hmm, and did you experience any other symptoms after that?
Patient: Yes, about 150 minutes later, I developed some meningitis symptoms like nausea, drowsiness, confusion, a stiff neck, and a positive Kernig sign.
Doctor: That sounds concerning. What kind of treatment did you receive initially?
Patient: I was given 1000 mg of Amoxicillin, 1000 mg of Paracetamol, and an IV dose of Ringer's lactate solution.
Doctor: Okay, and were you transferred to another medical facility after that?
Patient: Yes, by 9:30 A.M. I was transferred to the emergency department of Military Hospital 108 because I started showing symptoms of blood sepsis.
Doctor: I see. So you were diagnosed with meningitis and sepsis, correct?
Patient: That's right.
Doctor: And how were you treated for these conditions?
Patient: They treated me with ceftriaxone at a dose of 1 g, four times a day.
Doctor: Good. I understand that your cerebrospinal fluid was collected and a N. meningitidis culture was grown. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yeah, the culture they grew was designated as DuyDNT, and it was identified to belong to serogroup B.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that you recovered successfully after treatment. Now, on the topic of the DuyDNT isolate, it has been revealed to be a novel sequence type. It was assigned an ST 13074 by PubMLST, a public database that catalogs genetic data and isolate provenance of the Neisseria genus. Did you know that?
Patient: No, I didn't know that.
Doctor: By sequencing the seven housekeeping genes used in the MLST scheme, every N. meningitidis isolate can be assigned a sequence type (ST) and placed into groups and clonal complexes based on evolutionary relatedness. Besides DuyDNT, only two other isolates of ST 13074 have been found, both were carrier strains identified in Vietnam in 2017. ST 13074 shared ≥ 5 identical alleles at seven typed loci with three other STs (1576, 11013, and 13455), making it the central ST of this group by PubMLST group's definition.
Patient: Oh, I see. That's interesting.
Doctor: Yes, it is. Now, moving forward, it's essential that you continue monitoring your health and reporting any concerning symptoms to your healthcare provider. Keep up with any required follow-up appointments, and take care of yourself.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I'll make sure to keep an eye on my health and follow your advice.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports experiencing headaches, fatigue, fever, nausea, drowsiness, confusion, a stiff neck, and a positive Kernig sign since midnight, June 2014. Symptoms escalated to include signs of meningitis and later, blood sepsis. The patient was initially treated with Amoxicillin, Paracetamol, and Ringer's lactate solution, followed by a transfer to a specialized facility for further management.
O: Upon admission to Military Hospital 108, the patient was diagnosed with meningitis and sepsis and treated with 1 g of ceftriaxone four times daily. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis confirmed N. meningitidis, specifically a novel sequence type ST 13074, serogroup B. Vital signs and other specific objective data from the initial presentation are not provided.
A: The primary diagnosis is meningitis and sepsis due to N. meningitidis serogroup B, ST 13074. The patient's condition was severe, requiring immediate and intensive treatment including antibiotics and supportive care. The identification of a novel sequence type indicates a unique strain, potentially affecting treatment efficacy and public health monitoring.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's health for any recurrence of symptoms or new health issues. Ensure follow-up appointments are scheduled, particularly with infectious disease specialists for further evaluation and management. Educate the patient on signs of potential complications and the importance of adherence to prescribed treatments. Encourage the patient to maintain hydration, rest, and a balanced diet to support recovery.

transcript:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand you are a 19-year-old boy with a normal body mass index and normal blood pressure. You've lived in Tehran city and have been experiencing some health issues. Can you tell me about the symptoms you've been having?
Patient: Yeah, since March 2017, I've suffered from periodic febrile attacks with temperatures between 39-40°C. During these fever attacks, I've had many aphthous ulcers in my mouth, swollen glands in my neck, and a sore in the back of my throat.
Doctor: I see. How long do these fever periods typically last, and how often do they occur?
Patient: The fever periods usually last about 7 days. After the disease goes down, the next attack comes around 45 days later. I also feel weakness, severe fatigue in my limbs, and a slight abdominal pain in the LUQ area during the time of the attacks.
Doctor: Thank you for that information. I understand you were first admitted to the hospital in July 2017 during a severe fever attack due to weakness, lethargy, and high temperature. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. The doctors noticed my high fever of 39.8°C, severe aphthous mouth ulcers, inflammation in my throat, and swollen lymph nodes on my neck during the physical examination.
Doctor: During that time, they also examined your abdomen and found splenomegaly. After these examinations, they requested some laboratory tests to determine the cause of the disease. Do you remember what tests were done?
Patient: Yes, they did a bunch of tests, like urine culture, blood culture, stool exam, stool culture, HIV antibody, hepatitis B antigen, hepatitis C virus antibody, rheumatoid factor, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, peripheral blood smear, malaria, borrelia, fluorescent antinuclear antibody, and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide.
Doctor: I see. The results of all these tests were negative except for the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), which was 31. Did they perform an abdominal ultrasound examination to determine the size of your spleen?
Patient: Yes, they did. The ultrasound examination determined that my spleen was larger than normal, measuring 32 × 140.
Doctor: Thank you for providing all of this information. We will continue to monitor your condition and determine the best course of action for your treatment. It's important that you follow up with us regularly to track any changes in your symptoms or health.
Patient: Okay, thank you for your help, doctor. I'll make sure to schedule regular appointments to keep you updated.
soap_note:
S: The patient is a 19-year-old male from Tehran with a history of periodic febrile attacks since March 2017, presenting with high fevers (39-40°C), aphthous ulcers, swollen glands in the neck, and a sore throat. These episodes typically last about 7 days and recur approximately every 45 days. The patient also experiences weakness, severe fatigue, and slight abdominal pain in the left upper quadrant (LUQ) during these attacks. He was first hospitalized in July 2017 during a severe episode.
O: Physical examination during past hospitalization revealed high fever (39.8°C), severe aphthous mouth ulcers, throat inflammation, swollen lymph nodes, and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests including urine and blood cultures, stool exam and culture, tests for HIV, hepatitis B and C, rheumatoid factor, peripheral blood smear, malaria, borrelia, fluorescent antinuclear antibody, and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide were negative, except for an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 31. An abdominal ultrasound showed an enlarged spleen measuring 32 × 140 mm.
A: The patient's symptoms and test results suggest a periodic fever syndrome, possibly Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF) or another autoinflammatory disorder, given the negative infectious and autoimmune workup and the presence of splenomegaly and elevated ESR. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of periodic fever or lymphoproliferative disorders.
P: The management plan will include regular monitoring and follow-up appointments to track symptom progression and response to any treatments initiated. Further evaluation by a rheumatologist or a specialist in autoinflammatory diseases is recommended to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate therapy, possibly including colchicine or other anti-inflammatory medications. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, potential complications, and importance of compliance with follow-up visits is crucial.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you were diagnosed with bronchial asthma at 10 years of age and treated with inhalants. Have you received any treatment for asthma since then?
Patient: No, I stopped receiving treatment for asthma when I was 30 because of the resolution of bronchial asthma.
Doctor: I understand. You've been followed at our hospital for idiopathic interstitial pneumonia with annual regular chest X-ray and computed tomography (CT) scans for 4 years. Have you experienced any symptoms related to this?
Patient: No, I haven't had any symptoms, and the findings have been stable over the years.
Doctor: That's good to hear. We did a Chest X-ray and CT scan in December 2017, and it revealed a high-attenuation mucus plug in your right intermediate bronchial trunk, right pleural effusion (Fig. a), and infiltration in the right lung field (Fig. b). Additionally, we found unilateral bronchiectasis in the right upper lobe.
Patient: Oh, I didn't know that.
Doctor: We also did a CT of your paranasal sinuses due to your nasal congestion for 3 years, and it revealed a high-attenuation mucus plug in the left ethmoid sinuses. During your physical examination, we noticed decreased breath sounds in the right lower lung field. No wheezing and rhonchi were observed on auscultation.
Patient: Hmm, yes, I've had nasal congestion for a while now.
Doctor: Blood tests showed a total leucocyte count of 9300/mm3 with 8% eosinophils (absolute eosinophil count, 744/mm3) and elevated C-reactive protein. The radioimmunosorbent test revealed elevated IgE levels (1460 IU/ml). The radioimmunosorbent test for specific IgE antibodies against Aspergillus, Penicillium, and Candida were positive, as were serum precipitins to Aspergillus.
Patient: Okay, what does that mean?
Doctor: We also confirmed local urticaria and lash 15 minutes after a subcutaneous injection of A. fumigatus antigen, which is positive for an immediate cutaneous hypersensitivity reaction. You also have a history of right nephrectomy due to renal cancer, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Your pulmonary function test showed the following: forced vital capacity (FVC), 1.86 L (55.4% of predicted value); forced expiratory volume. It's important that we continue to monitor your condition and discuss appropriate treatment options if necessary.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me.
soap_note:
S: The patient, previously diagnosed with bronchial asthma at age 10 and treated with inhalants, reports cessation of asthma treatment at age 30 due to resolution. Currently, the patient is followed for idiopathic interstitial pneumonia, with no symptoms reported and stable findings over the years. The patient has had nasal congestion for three years and no recent exacerbation of respiratory symptoms.
O: The latest imaging studies, including a Chest X-ray and CT scan from December 2017, showed a high-attenuation mucus plug in the right intermediate bronchial trunk, right pleural effusion, infiltration in the right lung field, and unilateral bronchiectasis in the right upper lobe. CT of the paranasal sinuses indicated a high-attenuation mucus plug in the left ethmoid sinuses. Physical examination revealed decreased breath sounds in the right lower lung field, with no wheezing or rhonchi. Blood tests indicated a total leucocyte count of 9300/mm3 with 8% eosinophils (absolute count, 744/mm3), elevated C-reactive protein, and IgE levels at 1460 IU/ml. Positive serum precipitins and specific IgE antibodies against Aspergillus, Penicillium, and Candida were noted. A subcutaneous injection of A. fumigatus antigen resulted in local urticaria and lash, confirming an immediate cutaneous hypersensitivity reaction. Pulmonary function tests showed reduced forced vital capacity (FVC) at 1.86 L (55.4% of predicted value).
A: The patient presents with stable idiopathic interstitial pneumonia, evidence of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) suggested by imaging, eosinophilia, elevated IgE, and specific antibody response to fungi, and a history of bronchial asthma. Differential diagnoses include chronic sinusitis due to the presence of nasal congestion and sinus involvement.
P: Continue regular monitoring of idiopathic interstitial pneumonia with annual imaging. Initiate treatment for ABPA including corticosteroids and possibly antifungal therapy after further evaluation. Address nasal congestion and potential chronic sinusitis with appropriate medications and consider referral to an otolaryngologist. Educate the patient on the signs of ABPA exacerbation and the importance of regular follow-up. Ensure adherence to treatment plans and scheduled follow-ups to monitor disease progression and response to therapy.

transcript:
Doctor: Hi there, I see that you have a history of pulmonary sarcoidosis, hypertension, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), and obesity. Can you tell me how you're feeling today?
Patient: Well, I was doing some yard work earlier, and I suddenly had trouble seeing out of my right eye and had difficulty remembering names and events.
Doctor: I see. Let's discuss some of your previous test results to better understand your situation. Last year, during a preoperative evaluation for dental work, a 12-lead electrocardiogram found incidental PVCs. Holter monitoring showed a 12% PVC burden over 24 hours, which indicates an indeterminate degree of ventricular dysfunction. Do you remember these tests?
Patient: Yes, I remember going through those tests.
Doctor: Following those tests, we performed a transthoracic echocardiogram which revealed hypokinesis of the left inferior ventricular wall with an ejection fraction of 35%. Cardiac catheterization was also done to investigate structural blockages of coronary vessels, but it yielded no significant CAD. These findings were suspicious for an infiltrative process. Can you recall that?
Patient: Yeah, I remember the doctors mentioning something about that.
Doctor: We then conducted a cardiac MRI which showed sarcoid infiltrates on T2-weighted images, and a pulmonary node biopsy revealed noncaseating granulomas. Based on these findings, you were diagnosed with cardiac sarcoidosis three months after your initial presentation. At that time, you showed no clinical symptoms of systemic sarcoidosis or heart failure. An implantable cardioverter defibrillator was placed for primary prevention of arrhythmias secondary to cardiac sarcoid. Have you been feeling well since then?
Patient: Yes, I've been doing well for the past year until these recent stroke-like symptoms started.
Doctor: During your examination today, your speech and language seemed normal. I asked you to write a simple sentence, which you did without difficulty. However, when asked to read the sentence, you were unable to do so. This represents alexia without agraphia. Additionally, you showed right homonymous hemianopia. The rest of your physical exam was normal. 
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean for me?
Doctor: At admission, we performed an initial computed tomography (CT) scan which came back negative. We will conduct a subsequent brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to further investigate the cause of your symptoms.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me. What should I do next?
Doctor: We'll closely monitor your symptoms and follow up with the MRI results. In the meantime, please report any changes in your condition or any new symptoms that may arise. We'll work together to determine the best course of action for your situation.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: The patient, with a history of pulmonary sarcoidosis, hypertension, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), and obesity, reports sudden onset of difficulty seeing out of the right eye and trouble remembering names and events while doing yard work. The patient has been asymptomatic from cardiac sarcoidosis and heart failure for the past year until these recent symptoms began.
O: Last year's tests revealed PVCs with a 12% burden and hypokinesis of the left inferior ventricular wall with an ejection fraction of 35%. No significant coronary artery disease (CAD) was found. Cardiac MRI showed sarcoid infiltrates, and a pulmonary node biopsy confirmed noncaseating granulomas. Today's examination showed normal speech and language, ability to write but inability to read (alexia without agraphia), and right homonymous hemianopia. Initial CT scan of the brain was negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is suspected cerebrovascular accident (CVA) given the acute onset of visual and cognitive symptoms, specifically alexia without agraphia and right homonymous hemianopia. Differential diagnoses include transient ischemic attack (TIA) or a complication related to known cardiac sarcoidosis. The negative initial CT scan suggests a need for further imaging to confirm the diagnosis.
P: Plan to conduct a brain MRI to further investigate the cause of the stroke-like symptoms. Monitor the patient closely for any changes or progression of symptoms. Educate the patient on recognizing and reporting new or worsening symptoms. Follow up with MRI results and adjust the treatment plan based on findings. Ensure compliance with current medications for sarcoidosis, hypertension, and cardiac conditions.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've been referred to our center with complaints of painless jaundice. Before we begin, do you have any family history of cancer?
Patient: No, I don't have any family history of cancer.
Doctor: Alright. What about your medical history? Are there any significant conditions you've been treated for?
Patient: Yes, I had pulmonary tuberculosis in the past and I was treated with medications for that.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. When you were admitted, we performed a physical examination and found moderately icteric sclera and jaundice. The circulatory, respiratory, and abdominal examinations were unremarkable. We also conducted some laboratory tests. The results showed elevated total bilirubin of 403 μmol/L, aspartate aminotransaminase of 153 U/L, alanine aminophosphatase of 93 U/L, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) of 10.2 ng/mL, and carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA19-9) of 1073.6 U/mL. 
Patient: Hmm, I see. What do those numbers mean?
Doctor: These numbers indicate that you have high levels of bilirubin and certain enzymes, as well as elevated tumor markers, which could suggest a possible malignancy. We also performed a pulmonary computed tomography (CT) scan, which was negative except for a few areas of fibrosis resulting from your previous tuberculosis infection. Additionally, we conducted a magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography, which showed severe stenosis at the junction of the left and right common hepatic ducts and marked dilation of the intrahepatic bile ducts.
Patient: Oh, okay. What about my abdomen?
Doctor: An abdominal enhanced CT scan revealed a 2-cm mass in the hepatic hilum and regional lymph node enlargement. To relieve cholestasis and improve your liver function, we performed a percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage.
Patient: So, what's the diagnosis?
Doctor: Based on all these findings, we made a tentative diagnosis of Bismuth IV type pCCA. You underwent surgical resection, which included a left hemihepatectomy, cholecystectomy, and lymphadenectomy. The reconstruction was achieved by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.
Patient: Was the procedure successful?
Doctor: Yes, the procedure was considered curative since intraoperative frozen examination showed that the resection margin was free of atypical cells. Within the resected specimen, we found a yellowish tumor measuring 2 cm × 0.5 cm × 1 cm in the hilar bile duct. Microscopically, the tumor showed a nested organoid growth pattern.
Patient: What does that mean for my recovery?
Doctor: It means that the surgery was successful in removing the tumor and we believe that the cancer has been treated. However, it is important to have regular follow-up appointments to monitor your recovery and ensure that there are no signs of recurrence.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and I'll make sure to schedule those follow-up appointments.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns in the meantime, please don't hesitate to reach out. Take care and best wishes for your recovery.
soap_note:
S: The patient presents with painless jaundice. He has a past medical history of pulmonary tuberculosis treated with medications. He denies any family history of cancer.
O: Physical examination revealed moderately icteric sclera and jaundice, with unremarkable circulatory, respiratory, and abdominal findings. Laboratory tests showed elevated total bilirubin (403 μmol/L), aspartate aminotransaminase (153 U/L), alanine aminophosphatase (93 U/L), carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) (10.2 ng/mL), and carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA19-9) (1073.6 U/mL). Pulmonary CT scan indicated areas of fibrosis from previous tuberculosis. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography revealed severe stenosis at the junction of the left and right common hepatic ducts and marked dilation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. Abdominal enhanced CT scan showed a 2-cm mass in the hepatic hilum and regional lymph node enlargement. Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage was performed to relieve cholestasis.
A: The patient was diagnosed with Bismuth IV type perihilar cholangiocarcinoma (pCCA). The surgical resection included a left hemihepatectomy, cholecystectomy, and lymphadenectomy, with a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy for reconstruction. Intraoperative frozen examination confirmed the resection margin was free of atypical cells. The resected tumor measured 2 cm × 0.5 cm × 1 cm and showed a nested organoid growth pattern microscopically.
P: The surgery was considered curative. The patient is advised to have regular follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and check for signs of recurrence. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns during recovery.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented here today with a history of bilateral nasal obstruction. Can you tell me about that?
Patient: Yeah, I've had this problem for about 10 years. I actually had septoplasty and functional endoscopic sinus surgery 7 years ago at another hospital, but I didn't see much improvement in my symptoms.
Doctor: I see, so you still experience nasal obstruction. Can you tell me more about any other symptoms you've had since then?
Patient: Well, I've had this right nasolabial fold fullness for a year now, and it has increased in size over time. I also have right facial pain.
Doctor: Thank you for providing that information. During your clinical examination, we found a swelling in your right nasolabial fold, measuring 2x1 cm. It was tender to palpation and hard in consistency, but the skin over it appears normal. We also performed an anterior rhinoscopic examination of your right nasal cavity and found a lateral nasal wall swelling that is obliterating about 90% of your nasal vestibule. The mucosa and skin color externally appear normal.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: To further investigate the issue, we performed computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans. The images revealed a well-defined subcutaneous soft tissue density measuring 1.6x1.6 cm in your right nasolabial fold. The lesion demonstrated isointensity with no drop in fat saturation on T1 but showed hypointensity on T2 and homogeneous enhancement postcontrast.
Patient: So, what did you do about it?
Doctor: In August 2014, you underwent surgical excision of the mass through a sublabial approach. The mass was encapsulated with no infiltration to surrounding tissues, and it was excised completely with its capsule. You had an uncomplicated postoperative period.
Patient: That's a relief. What did you find out about the mass?
Doctor: Histopathological examination of the mass revealed spindle cell proliferation, forming fascicles and whorls on a background of collagen fibers. The fascicles were associated with foci of mixed inflammatory cells infiltrate, composed mainly of lymphocytes and plasma cells, along with scattered eosinophils and neutrophils. The lesion infiltrated the surrounding striated muscles and fatty tissue but did not infiltrate the cutaneous and subcutaneous tissue.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that the lesion was affecting some of the surrounding tissues, but not the skin or the fatty tissue beneath the skin. We also performed immunohistochemical studies on the spindle cells and found that they were diffusely positive for vimentin and smooth muscle actin (SMA) and focally positive for anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK). In contrast, they were negative for S100, CD34, P-catenin, CD99, and epithelial membrane.
Patient: So, what's the plan now?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your progress and recovery. It's important that you report any new or worsening symptoms. We will schedule follow-up appointments to ensure that the excision was successful and that there are no further complications or recurrence of the mass.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports a history of bilateral nasal obstruction for 10 years, with previous septoplasty and functional endoscopic sinus surgery 7 years ago, which did not significantly improve symptoms. Recently, the patient has experienced right nasolabial fold fullness for a year, which has increased in size, accompanied by right facial pain.
O: Clinical examination revealed a 2x1 cm hard, tender swelling in the right nasolabial fold with normal overlying skin. Anterior rhinoscopy showed a lateral nasal wall swelling obliterating about 90% of the nasal vestibule, with normal mucosa and skin color. CT and MRI scans identified a well-defined 1.6x1.6 cm subcutaneous soft tissue density in the right nasolabial fold, isointense on T1, hypointense on T2, and showing homogeneous enhancement post-contrast. Histopathological examination post-surgical excision showed spindle cell proliferation with mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate, and immunohistochemical studies showed positivity for vimentin and SMA, focal positivity for ALK, and negativity for S100, CD34, P-catenin, CD99, and epithelial membrane antigen.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign spindle cell lesion in the right nasolabial fold, likely a benign fibrous histiocytoma or a low-grade sarcoma, given the histopathological and immunohistochemical findings. Differential diagnoses could include other soft tissue tumors. The prognosis is generally good given the complete excision and lack of infiltration into cutaneous and subcutaneous tissues.
P: The patient will be monitored for any new or worsening symptoms, with scheduled follow-up appointments to ensure no recurrence or complications post-excision. Emphasis will be placed on patient education regarding signs of recurrence and the importance of regular follow-up.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've consulted with us today due to aggravated lower abdominal pain for the past 6 days, along with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I understand. Do you have any past medical history we should be aware of?
Patient: Yes, I have a history of hypertension, and I've been treated with amlodipine besylate tablets for it.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. During your examination, we found rebound tenderness at the McBurney's point, but your bowel sounds were normal. We also conducted a laboratory examination upon admission, which showed your white blood cell (WBC) count at 20.31*10^9/L and your neutrophilic granulocyte percentage (N%) at 94.3%. These results indicate an infection. To further assess your condition, we performed an abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan.
Patient: What did the CT scan show?
Doctor: The CT scan revealed gas in your intra- and extra-hepatic portal and mesenteric veins, in addition to appendicitis with peripheral peritonitis. Due to these findings, we planned an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy. However, I understand you rejected this option?
Patient: Yes, I was scared and didn't want to go through surgery.
Doctor: I understand your concerns. As an alternative, we started conservative treatment with antibiotics, specifically Piperacillin Sodium and Tazobactam Sodium for Injection. Over the following 4 days, your abdominal pain became generalized, and signs of diffused peritonitis and borborygmus gradually disappeared. Unfortunately, there were no decreases in your inflammatory markers after the antibiotic treatment.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: We conducted a repeated abdominal CT scan, which showed the absence of gas in your intra- and extra-hepatic portal and superior mesenteric veins. However, the scan also revealed enhanced pneumatosis cystoides intestinalis and a dilated small intestine, which had become more severe. Additionally, the appendicitis with peripheral peritonitis was still present.
Patient: So what's the next step?
Doctor: Based on your abdominal signs and changes in laboratory and imaging examination results, we suspected intestinal necrosis. We performed an emergency laparotomy on the fifth day of admission to further investigate.
Patient: What did you find during the surgery?
Doctor: The intra-operative findings confirmed the diagnosis of a suppurated appendix, with about 20 ml of purulent secretion around it. We also observed remarkable necrosis, approximately 100 cm, in the small intestinal wall and mesentery. Furthermore, there was an intestinal perforation in the necrotic bowel.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is a critical situation, but we will do our best to manage your condition and guide you through the recovery process. It's essential to follow all postoperative care instructions and attend follow-up appointments as scheduled. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out to us.
soap_note:
S: Patient presents with aggravated lower abdominal pain for the past 6 days, accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. The patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on amlodipine besylate. The patient initially rejected surgical intervention due to fear.
O: Physical examination revealed rebound tenderness at McBurney's point, normal bowel sounds. Laboratory tests showed elevated WBC count at 20.31*10^9/L (normal range: 4.0-11.0*10^9/L) and high neutrophil percentage at 94.3% (normal range: 40-74%). Initial CT scan indicated appendicitis with peripheral peritonitis and gas in portal and mesenteric veins. Follow-up CT scan showed enhanced pneumatosis cystoides intestinalis, worsened dilation of the small intestine, and persistent appendicitis with peripheral peritonitis. Emergency laparotomy confirmed a suppurated appendix, significant necrosis of the small intestine, and an intestinal perforation.
A: The primary diagnosis is appendicitis complicated by intestinal necrosis and perforation. Differential diagnosis initially included less severe gastrointestinal conditions, but imaging and surgical findings confirmed severe appendicitis and complications.
P: The patient underwent emergency laparotomy after conservative treatment with Piperacillin Sodium and Tazobactam Sodium failed to improve symptoms and inflammatory markers. Postoperative care includes close monitoring, antibiotics to prevent infection, pain management, and regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any potential complications. The importance of adherence to postoperative instructions and follow-up care was emphasized to the patient.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see in your past medical history that you have severe allergy-induced asthma and chronic nasal drip. What brings you to the clinic today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been having a worsening cough and chest tightness for the past 10 days.
Doctor: I see. Have you been treated for this issue recently?
Patient: Yes, I was treated for bronchitis with steroids and antibiotics, but my symptoms didn't improve.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let's discuss your recent emergency department visit. What were your symptoms at that time?
Patient: I had severe and sudden shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain, and sharp radiating pain between both shoulder blades when I took a deep breath.
Doctor: At the time of presentation, you were afebrile and your vital signs were within normal limits. Your lab work, including negative leukocyte count and cardiac enzymes, was also insignificant. However, a chest X-ray demonstrated an abnormal right cardiomediastinal silhouette with a large opacity over the right mediastinum adjacent to the right atrial border. A follow-up CT scan revealed a large right-sided mass measuring 5.1 cm × 9 cm × 4.3 cm. Your last imaging study, a fluoroscopy 10 years ago, showed no indications for a mediastinal mass. An echocardiogram showed a normal ejection fraction (55–59%), no wall motion abnormalities, and a cyst near the right atrium. Due to your continued pleuritic chest pain and difficulty breathing, we decided to perform video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) for pericardial cyst removal.
Patient: Oh, I see. What happened during the surgery?
Doctor: During the surgery, you underwent general anesthesia with a 37 French left-sided double-lumen tube. Standard ASA monitors were applied. Two large-bore peripheral IVs and an arterial line were placed for continuous blood pressure monitoring. Intraoperatively, we found a large cystic lesion adherent to the pericardium. There was no solid component and no obvious communication with the pericardium. Part of the cyst wall was left on the phrenic nerve to preserve it.
Patient: How did I do after the procedure?
Doctor: You tolerated the procedure well, had no postoperative complications, and were discharged home on postoperative day number two. The final pathology report revealed a benign, acute inflammatory pericardial cyst.
Patient: That's a relief. Thank you for explaining everything, doctor.
soap_note:
S: The patient, with a history of severe allergy-induced asthma and chronic nasal drip, presented with a worsening cough and chest tightness persisting for 10 days. Previously treated for bronchitis with steroids and antibiotics without improvement. Reported severe and sudden shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain, and sharp pain radiating between both shoulder blades during deep breaths.
O: Initial vital signs were within normal limits; afebrile. Lab work showed negative leukocyte count and cardiac enzymes. Chest X-ray revealed an abnormal right cardiomediastinal silhouette with a large opacity adjacent to the right atrial border. CT scan identified a large right-sided mass (5.1 cm × 9 cm × 4.3 cm). Echocardiogram indicated normal ejection fraction (55–59%), no wall motion abnormalities, and a cyst near the right atrium. Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) was performed, revealing a large cystic lesion adherent to the pericardium, with no solid component or communication with the pericardium. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, and pathology confirmed a benign, acute inflammatory pericardial cyst.
A: Primary diagnosis of a benign pericardial cyst with associated symptoms of pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath. Differential diagnoses previously considered included bronchitis and other mediastinal masses.
P: The patient underwent successful surgical removal of the pericardial cyst via VATS, with preservation of the phrenic nerve. Postoperative management included monitoring and standard post-surgical care, resulting in discharge on postoperative day two without complications. Follow-up care will involve monitoring for recurrence of respiratory symptoms and regular check-ups to assess postoperative recovery and lung function. Education provided on signs of infection or complications requiring immediate medical attention.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. About 7 weeks ago, I was at a baseball game and I gazed at the sun several times. After that, I started experiencing central scotoma and decreased vision in both eyes.
Doctor: I see. Are you taking any medications for any other conditions?
Patient: Yes, I'm taking etizolam for a psychiatric condition, panic disorder.
Doctor: Alright, thank you for sharing that information. We conducted a series of tests during your first visit. Your decimal best corrected visual acuity was 0.8 in the right eye and 0.7 in the left eye. We also performed Slit lamp examinations, which showed no abnormalities in the anterior segments and media of both eyes. Additionally, we conducted fluorescein angiography and indocyanine green angiography, which indicated no remarkable abnormalities in either eye.
Patient: Okay, and what about the OCT images?
Doctor: The OCT images showed an elevated and blurred ellipsoid zone along with loss of the interdigitation zone at the foveal area bilaterally. There was no vitreomacular adhesion or traction seen in either of the eyes.
Patient: So, what's the diagnosis, Doctor?
Doctor: Based on your symptoms and the findings from the tests, you have been diagnosed with solar retinopathy. This condition is likely a result of the sun gazing incident you mentioned earlier.
Patient: Oh, I see. What's the treatment plan then?
Doctor: We started treatment during your first visit. You were given a posterior sub-Tenon triamcinolone injection in your right eye, followed by oral prednisolone therapy.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything, Doctor. I hope this treatment will help improve my vision.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will monitor your progress and adjust the treatment plan if necessary. It's important to avoid sun gazing in the future to prevent further damage to your eyes. If you have any concerns or notice any changes in your vision, please don't hesitate to contact us. Take care.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a known case of panic disorder on etizolam, reports experiencing central scotoma and decreased vision in both eyes for 7 weeks following repeated sun gazing at a baseball game.
O: Decimal best corrected visual acuity was measured at 0.8 in the right eye and 0.7 in the left eye. Slit lamp examinations revealed no abnormalities in the anterior segments and media of both eyes. Fluorescein angiography and indocyanine green angiography showed no remarkable abnormalities. OCT images indicated an elevated and blurred ellipsoid zone and loss of the interdigitation zone at the foveal area bilaterally, with no vitreomacular adhesion or traction.
A: The patient is diagnosed with solar retinopathy, likely due to sun gazing. The absence of other abnormalities in angiography and slit lamp examinations supports this diagnosis.
P: Treatment initiated with a posterior sub-Tenon triamcinolone injection in the right eye and oral prednisolone therapy. The patient is advised to avoid sun gazing and to monitor and report any changes in vision. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and make adjustments as necessary.

transcript:
Doctor: Hi there, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing severe burning pain and tingling sensation in my lower limbs for the past six months. It's been getting worse, and now it's affecting my upper limbs too. I'm unable to walk or eat alone anymore.
Doctor: I see. Have you ever been diagnosed with any medical conditions in the past?
Patient: Yes, I was diagnosed with HIV infection five years ago at another tertiary care hospital, but I refused follow-up.
Doctor: I understand. Given your symptoms and medical history, let's start with a neurological examination. We'll also need to run some tests to figure out what's going on.
(After the examination and tests)
Doctor: Your neurological examination showed lethargy, disorientation, and psychomotor slowing. Your motor strength is also asymmetrically diminished, with a Medical Research Council Scale of grade 2/5 in right upper limb extension, grade 3/5 in bilateral lower limb extension, and grade 4/5 in the remaining. Your deep tendon reflexes are symmetrical, except for absent right brachioradialis and bilateral patellar reflexes. You also have impaired pin-prick sensibility in the right ulnar and radial distribution. However, the rest of your physical examination was unremarkable.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We also conducted a brain MRI and an electromyography (EMG) test. The MRI is consistent with HIV encephalopathy, and the EMG shows severe confluent multifocal demyelination and axonal loss in both your upper and lower limbs. This indicates MNM as the diagnosis.
Patient: What about my blood tests?
Doctor: Your CD4 cell count is at 75 cells/μL (8%), and your HIV RNA is 633,000 copies/mL. Your CMV DNA in blood is 64,000 copies/mL, with CMV antigen being negative. CMV IgG antibodies are positive, and IgM antibodies are negative. Your previous medical records confirmed prior CMV IgG seropositivity, suggesting CMV reactivation.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: We also analyzed your cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), which showed 7 cells, protein of 1.19 g/dL, and glucose of 49 mg/dL. Bacterial and fungal cultures were negative, but CMV DNA was positive at 14,400 cp/mL and HIV RNA at 184,222 cp/mL. We also found gastrointestinal involvement by disseminated CMV disease, even though you reported no related symptoms. Retinal involvement has been excluded.
Patient: So what's the cause of my symptoms?
Doctor: The most likely cause of your MNM is disseminated CMV disease. We're going to start you on IV ganciclovir as treatment.
Patient: Okay, thank you for helping me figure out what's going on. I hope the treatment helps.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll monitor your progress closely and make adjustments as needed. It's important that you continue with regular follow-up appointments to ensure the best possible outcome.
soap_note:
S: Patient reports severe burning pain and tingling sensation in lower limbs for the past six months, worsening and now affecting upper limbs. Unable to walk or eat alone. Diagnosed with HIV five years ago, no follow-up since diagnosis.
O: Neurological examination shows lethargy, disorientation, psychomotor slowing, asymmetrically diminished motor strength (MRC Scale: 2/5 right upper limb, 3/5 bilateral lower limbs, 4/5 remaining), absent right brachioradialis and bilateral patellar reflexes, impaired pin-prick sensibility in right ulnar and radial distribution. Brain MRI indicates HIV encephalopathy. EMG reveals severe confluent multifocal demyelination and axonal loss in upper and lower limbs. CD4 count is 75 cells/μL, HIV RNA is 633,000 copies/mL, CMV DNA in blood is 64,000 copies/mL, CMV IgG positive, IgM negative. CSF analysis shows 7 cells, protein 1.19 g/dL, glucose 49 mg/dL, positive CMV DNA at 14,400 cp/mL, and HIV RNA at 184,222 cp/mL. No retinal involvement by CMV.
A: Primary diagnosis of Mononeuritis Multiplex (MNM) secondary to disseminated CMV disease in the context of advanced HIV infection and HIV encephalopathy. Differential diagnosis includes other opportunistic infections due to severe immunosuppression.
P: Initiate IV ganciclovir for CMV treatment. Monitor CD4 count and viral loads closely. Regular neurological assessments and follow-up appointments to adjust treatment as necessary. Educate patient on the importance of adherence to treatment and follow-up to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that your baby was born through cesarean section at 37 weeks due to the cord being around his neck. Can you tell me about your baby's mother's reproductive history?
Patient's Family: Yes, she had an abnormal reproductive history. Her first baby died of convulsion at 23 days after birth, and her second pregnancy was ectopic.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Now, I understand that this patient was referred here due to intermittent convulsions for more than 2 months and an exacerbation for 2 days. Can you describe the convulsions?
Patient's Family: They would happen while he was awake or asleep, but he didn't have a fever. He would go back to normal without any movement disorders afterward.
Doctor: I see. And how has his overall condition been lately?
Patient's Family: He has presented with decreased attention, poor head control, and thumb abduction.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. We've conducted a cerebral MRI which revealed patchy hyperintensity in the bilateral frontal and parietal lobe on T2WI. We also noted widened ventricles and the interval outside the cerebral. His EEG showed sleep spindle asynchrony.
Patient's Family: Oh no, what does that mean?
Doctor: These findings indicate brain abnormalities that could be contributing to the convulsions. Additionally, Blood gas analysis indicated metabolic acidosis, and GHB in his urine was significantly elevated according to the urinary organic acid analysis. 
Patient's Family: That's very concerning. What's the cause of all this?
Doctor: We've identified a homozygous mutation variant, c.1529C > T (p.S510F), in exon 10 of the ALDH5A1 gene in the patient. Subsequent targeted mutational analysis of exon 10 of his mother confirmed the segregation of the variant. The healthy father did not carry the sequence variant. The p.S510 mutation is highly conserved, and its mutation is predicted to be "Probably damaging."
Patient's Family: Oh, that's so unfortunate. What can be done for him?
Doctor: Unfortunately, I have some sad news. Despite our best efforts, the patient has passed away due to pneumonia. Our team tried everything we could to save him, but his condition was too severe.
Patient's Family: We appreciate everything you have done. Thank you for trying to help him.
Doctor: I'm truly sorry for your loss. If you have any questions or need support during this difficult time, please don't hesitate to reach out to us.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a neonate born at 37 weeks via cesarean section due to nuchal cord, presented with intermittent convulsions for over 2 months, worsening over the past 2 days. The convulsions occurred during both wakefulness and sleep, without fever, and resolved without residual movement disorders. The family history revealed a previous neonatal death due to convulsions and an ectopic pregnancy. Recently, the patient exhibited decreased attention, poor head control, and thumb abduction.
O: Cerebral MRI showed patchy hyperintensity in the bilateral frontal and parietal lobes on T2WI, widened ventricles, and external cerebral spacing. EEG indicated sleep spindle asynchrony. Blood gas analysis revealed metabolic acidosis. Urinary organic acid analysis showed significantly elevated GHB. Genetic testing identified a homozygous mutation, c.1529C > T (p.S510F), in exon 10 of the ALDH5A1 gene, confirmed in the mother and absent in the healthy father.
A: The primary diagnosis was a genetic disorder related to the ALDH5A1 gene mutation, leading to severe neurological symptoms and metabolic disturbances. Differential diagnoses initially considered included other causes of neonatal seizures and metabolic disorders. The prognosis was poor due to the severe brain abnormalities and genetic findings.
P: Management included supportive care for convulsions and metabolic acidosis, with close monitoring of neurological status and metabolic parameters. Genetic counseling was provided to the family to discuss the implications of the genetic findings. Unfortunately, the patient succumbed to complications from pneumonia. Bereavement support and further genetic counseling for the family were recommended.

transcript:
Doctor: Hi there, I see in your report that you're a 58-year-old African American male with a history of scaly, itchy feet. How long have you been experiencing this issue?
Patient: Yeah, doctor, I've had this problem for quite a while now.
Doctor: I understand. When you first presented to the clinic on February 8th, 2018, there was an inflammatory reaction on the plantar surface of both of your feet. We took a specimen collection from the plantar surface, and under KOH preparation, we found hyphae indicative of a fungal infection. This led to the diagnosis of a tinea pedis infection. Does that sound familiar?
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: We treated your infection with ketoconazole topical cream and 20% Urea creams, which you were instructed to apply daily. When you came back for a follow-up approximately 6 weeks later, we noticed a resolution of the underlying fungal infection, with minimal remaining inflammation. 
Patient: Yeah, I noticed improvement after using those creams.
Doctor: Given your initial presentation, we considered the possibility of an exaggerated immune reaction caused by Trichophyton, instead of just a cutaneous fungal infection alone. We suspected that you might have an underlying allergic response, specifically a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction to the fungus. To test this hypothesis, we performed intradermal skin testing on you.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: On March 21, 2018, you underwent application of Candida, normal saline, and Trichophyton allergens on your left volar forearm. Do you recall that?
Patient: Yes, I remember the test.
Doctor: Based on the test results, we can better understand the cause of your symptoms and determine the most effective course of treatment. It's essential to keep an eye on your feet and report any changes or worsening of your condition.
Patient: Okay, I will make sure to do that.
Doctor: Great. We will continue to monitor your progress, and I'll see you at your next appointment. If you have any concerns in the meantime, please don't hesitate to reach out.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: The patient is a 58-year-old African American male who reports a longstanding history of scaly, itchy feet. He recalls being diagnosed with tinea pedis following a positive KOH test showing hyphae and has been treated with ketoconazole and 20% Urea creams. He acknowledges improvement post-treatment but is aware of the need for ongoing monitoring due to potential underlying allergic reactions to the fungus.
O: Initial presentation included inflammatory reactions on the plantar surfaces of both feet. Follow-up showed resolution of the fungal infection with minimal remaining inflammation. Intradermal skin testing with Candida, normal saline, and Trichophyton allergens was performed on the left volar forearm to assess for delayed-type hypersensitivity, which could explain the exaggerated immune response.
A: The primary diagnosis is tinea pedis, effectively treated with topical antifungals. The differential diagnosis includes an exaggerated immune response to Trichophyton, suggesting a possible delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction. The prognosis is good with continued treatment and monitoring.
P: The management plan includes continued use of antifungal creams as needed and regular monitoring of the condition. The patient is advised to monitor for any changes or worsening of symptoms and report them promptly. Follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen to prevent recurrence.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've recently been diagnosed with advanced stage ovarian cancer. Can you tell me what symptoms led you to consult your general practitioner?
Patient: Yeah, I went to see my doctor because I was experiencing abdominal distension.
Doctor: I understand. Your test results, including abdominal computed tomography, serum CA125 determination, and laparoscopy, revealed that you have peritoneal carcinomatosis. This led to your diagnosis of stage III ovarian cancer, according to the FIGO classification.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is a serious condition. Based on your diagnosis, our institutional tumor board recommended a carboplatin-paclitaxel based chemotherapy regimen in a neoadjuvant setting. We also decided that a debulking surgery with hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) would be necessary.
Patient: Okay, so what happened next?
Doctor: A CVL was inserted via your right jugular vein into the superior vena cava in prevision of the surgery, and the positioning of the catheter was verified by chest x-ray. You also had an implantable central venous catheter (Port-a-Cath) put in place.
Patient: I remember that.
Doctor: In the first 48 postoperative hours, you experienced difficult pain management, hypotension, and transient hyperlactatemia. We managed these issues with fluid replacement and norepinephrine.
Patient: Yeah, it was a rough couple of days.
Doctor: On postoperative day 3, you presented with acute onset dyspnea when transferred from the bed to a chair, and your pulse oxygen saturation dropped from 96% to 83%. We administered oxygen at 5 L/min via a nasal cannula to help you breathe better.
Patient: I felt really short of breath then.
Doctor: During your physical examination, your body temperature was 37.4 °C, blood pressure 135/81 mmHg, heart rate 122 beats/min, and respiratory rate 20/min. You didn't report any chest pain, but your pulmonary examination revealed a bilateral reduction of basal breath sounds with dullness at percussion.
Patient: What did the chest x-ray show?
Doctor: The chest x-ray showed bilateral pleural effusions, which could explain your dyspnea and oxygen desaturation. We switched your oxygen delivery from a nasal cannula to a nonrebreather mask with a FiO2 of 0.40, which seemed to stabilize your condition in a supine position.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: We also took a measurement of the arteriovenous oxygen difference by sampling through your arterial and central venous line after you were in a supine position. This will help us monitor your progress and adjust your treatment as needed.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a female diagnosed with stage III ovarian cancer, reported abdominal distension as her initial symptom leading to further medical evaluation. She has undergone neoadjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel, followed by debulking surgery and HIPEC. Postoperatively, she experienced significant pain, hypotension, and hyperlactatemia, which were managed with fluid replacement and norepinephrine. On postoperative day 3, she developed acute dyspnea and oxygen desaturation upon mobilization, without chest pain.
O: Abdominal CT and laparoscopy confirmed peritoneal carcinomatosis. Serum CA125 was elevated (specific value not provided). Post-surgery, the patient had a CVL placed via the right jugular vein, and a Port-a-Cath was installed. Physical examination revealed a temperature of 37.4 °C, blood pressure 135/81 mmHg, heart rate 122 bpm, and respiratory rate 20/min. Pulmonary examination showed bilateral reduction of basal breath sounds and dullness at percussion. Chest x-ray indicated bilateral pleural effusions. Oxygen therapy was adjusted to a nonrebreather mask with FiO2 of 0.40, stabilizing her condition.
A: The primary diagnosis is stage III ovarian cancer with peritoneal carcinomatosis. Postoperative complications include difficult pain management, hypotension, hyperlactatemia, and acute respiratory distress likely secondary to bilateral pleural effusions. The patient's current status post-intervention is stable with ongoing monitoring.
P: Continue monitoring vital signs and oxygen saturation closely, adjusting oxygen delivery as needed. Manage pain and cardiovascular stability with appropriate medications. Follow up on arteriovenous oxygen difference measurements to assess respiratory and circulatory function. Schedule a follow-up with oncology to evaluate the effectiveness of the chemotherapy regimen and discuss further treatment options. Educate the patient on signs of infection or complications to watch for and ensure she understands the importance of follow-up appointments.

transcript:
Doctor: Hi there, I see that you were admitted to our medical ward with a 1-month history of dyspnea and a 2-day history of hemoptysis. Can you tell me more about these symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having trouble breathing for a month now, and I've been coughing up blood for the past couple of days.
Doctor: I also see that you reported a one-year history of a painless left testicular mass. Have you ever experienced any backache or have a known family history of testicular cancer?
Patient: No, I haven't had any backache, and I don't know of any family history of testicular cancer.
Doctor: During your examination, you were found to be dyspneic with an oxygen saturation of 83% on room air. We placed a facemask oxygen to help with your breathing. You also had marked gynecomastia and a firm, irregular, nontender left testicular mass measuring about 10 cm × 7 cm. There was no neurological deficit present on admission. You were then transferred to the urology ward and then urgently referred to the oncology department at another institution. 
Patient: Oh, I see. What did the tests show?
Doctor: Your chest X-ray showed cannon ball lesions, which can be indicative of metastatic disease. Your Hemoglobin level was 4.9 g/dL, which is quite low compared to the normal range of 13.4-17.5 g/dL. Your Beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (βhCG) was 807,593 IU/L, which is significantly elevated since the normal range is 0. 
Patient: What about the other tests?
Doctor: Your Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) was 2.4 μg/L, which is within the normal range of 0.0-7.0 μg/L. Your Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) was 1052 U/L, slightly above the normal range of 48-115 U/L. Your Calcium level was 1.69 mmol/L, a bit lower than the normal range of 2.15-2.50 mmol/L. And your Alkaline phosphatase was 57 U/L, within the normal range of 53-128 U/L.
Patient: So, what does all this mean?
Doctor: After your radical orchidectomy, the histopathology assessment showed an enlarged left testis measuring 100 × 60 × 55 mm. The cut surface had a nodular appearance with areas of hemorrhage, necrosis, and solid gray tumor nodules. The tunica appeared intact, and the spermatic cord seemed to be uninvolved. Microscopic examination confirmed the presence of a mixed germ cell tumor.
Patient: What's the next step for me?
Doctor: Your case will be managed by the oncology department at the other institution. They will determine the best course of treatment and follow-up care for your specific case. It's important to stay in close communication with your oncology team and follow their recommendations.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me. I'll make sure to stay in touch with my oncology team.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a male, reports a 1-month history of dyspnea and a 2-day history of hemoptysis. He also mentions a one-year history of a painless left testicular mass. He denies any backache and is unaware of any family history of testicular cancer.
O: On physical examination, the patient was dyspneic with an oxygen saturation of 83% on room air, which required facemask oxygen supplementation. He exhibited marked gynecomastia and a firm, irregular, nontender left testicular mass measuring 10 cm × 7 cm. Neurological examination showed no deficits. Chest X-ray revealed cannonball lesions suggestive of metastatic disease. Lab results showed a Hemoglobin level of 4.9 g/dL, βhCG of 807,593 IU/L, AFP of 2.4 μg/L, LDH of 1052 U/L, Calcium of 1.69 mmol/L, and Alkaline phosphatase of 57 U/L. Post-radical orchidectomy, histopathology confirmed a mixed germ cell tumor of the left testis.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic testicular cancer, indicated by the presence of a testicular mass, elevated βhCG, and cannonball lesions on chest X-ray. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hemoptysis and dyspnea, but these are less likely given the current findings.
P: The patient has been urgently referred to the oncology department for further management, which will likely include chemotherapy given the metastatic nature of the disease. The patient has been advised to maintain close communication with the oncology team and adhere to the treatment plan they recommend. Follow-up will be crucial to monitor response to therapy and manage any complications from the disease or treatment.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented your 2-year-old son to the local ophthalmologist due to an issue with his left eye, and now you've been transferred to our pediatric emergency department for further evaluation. Can you please tell me more about the problem he's been experiencing?
Patient's Parent: Yes, my son suddenly developed a dysfunction in the lateral movement of his left eye. It's causing a continuous abduction deficit and a fixated turn of his head to the left side.
Doctor: I see. Has he had any history of trauma, headache, vomiting, or fever recently?
Patient's Parent: No, he's generally fit and well. His medical history doesn't include any of those symptoms. He also hasn't had any vaccinations within the last few weeks.
Doctor: That's good to know. Did you notice any other symptoms, such as gait instability or other neurological deficits?
Patient's Parent: Well, he has had a mild gait instability, but no other concomitant symptoms or focal neurological deficits were found on his clinical examination.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Has your son been suffering from any chronic diseases or taking any regular medication?
Patient's Parent: No, he doesn't suffer from any chronic diseases and doesn't take any regular medication. His vaccination status is complete according to national recommendations.
Doctor: Alright. Have there been any recent illnesses in your family, like a respiratory tract infection or COVID-19?
Patient's Parent: Yes, three weeks prior to these symptoms, my son had a respiratory tract infection with an increased respiratory rate, dry cough, intermittent fever, and loss of appetite. It lasted for about two weeks. His local pediatrician provided symptomatic treatment, thinking it was a common cold. No swab for SARS-CoV-2 or other viruses was done. Around the same time, his father and uncle developed cough, dyspnea, sore throat, and muscle aches. His uncle tested positive for SARS-CoV-2.
Doctor: I see. Were the patient's relatives vaccinated for COVID-19?
Patient's Parent: No, they were unvaccinated as the COVID-19 vaccines were still unavailable for the general public at that time.
Doctor: Thank you for this information. On admission, we've conducted some tests. His laboratory inflammatory markers, including C-reactive protein, were negative. His full blood count showed mild thrombocytopenia but was unremarkable otherwise. We have also performed cranial contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging.
Patient's Parent: What do these test results mean for my son? What would be the next steps?
Doctor: The test results are helpful in understanding your son's condition. We will carefully analyze the imaging and blood test results and discuss this with our team. Based on the findings, we will determine the best course of action and any necessary follow-up requirements. We will keep you informed about any further steps or treatments needed for your son.
Patient's Parent: Thank you, doctor. We appreciate your help and attention to our son's case.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a 2-year-old male, presented with a sudden onset of dysfunction in the lateral movement of his left eye, characterized by a continuous abduction deficit. The patient's parent reports that this has resulted in a fixated turn of the head to the left side. The patient has a history of a recent respiratory tract infection but no history of trauma, headache, vomiting, fever, or chronic diseases. He has experienced mild gait instability but no other neurological deficits.
O: On examination, no focal neurological deficits were noted. The patient's vaccination status is up to date. Laboratory tests showed mild thrombocytopenia but were otherwise unremarkable, and inflammatory markers were negative. Cranial contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has been performed, the results of which are pending.
A: The primary concern is the sudden onset of abduction deficit in the left eye, possibly indicative of an acute neurological issue such as sixth cranial nerve palsy. The recent respiratory infection and family history of COVID-19 raise the possibility of a post-infectious etiology. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cranial nerve dysfunction.
P: The management plan will include a thorough review of the MRI results by the pediatric neurology team to assess for any structural or inflammatory causes. Symptomatic treatment for eye movement dysfunction may be considered. The patient will be monitored for any progression of symptoms or emergence of new symptoms. Further consultations with pediatric neurology and possibly infectious disease specialists will be arranged as needed. The family will be kept informed of all findings and involved in decision-making for any further interventions or treatments.

transcript:
Doctor: Hi there, I see that you're here for a heart transplant evaluation. Can you tell me a bit about your symptoms and medical history?
Patient: Yeah, when I was 10, I first had dyspnea and a holosystolic murmur at my apex. And I have a family history of CM.
Doctor: I see. And what did the echocardiography reveal at that time?
Patient: It showed a 3.5 x 4.8-cm mass in my LA. It was mobile, heterogeneous, and protruded from the atrial septum into LA, causing mitral regurgitation.
Doctor: Okay, and then you underwent a tumor removal surgery via midline sternotomy, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And the pathology report confirmed the diagnosis of CM?
Patient: Yes, it showed myxoid stroma with clusters of spindle cells and small blood vessels.
Doctor: I understand. Now, let's move forward to when you were 12 years old. You presented to the emergency department with sudden abdominal and right leg pain, right?
Patient: Yes, exactly.
Doctor: What did the abdominal examination show at that time?
Patient: I had left upper abdominal tenderness and guarding.
Doctor: And were there signs of arterial occlusion in your right leg?
Patient: Yes, there were.
Doctor: The echocardiogram at that time showed multiple cardiac masses in your LA and LV, correct?
Patient: Yes, it did.
Doctor: And a computed tomography of your abdomen and lower extremities confirmed the diagnosis of splenic infarction and femoral arterial embolism?
Patient: That's correct.
Doctor: So you underwent a splenectomy and embolectomy, as well as an open heart operation to remove the masses?
Patient: Yes, and all the specimens were reported as CM.
Doctor: I'm glad the surgery was uneventful, and the postoperative echocardiography showed no tumor residual. Was there any sign of Carney complex in your physical examination?
Patient: No, there wasn't.
Doctor: Unfortunately, at the age of 13, a right ventricular mass was detected on your echocardiography. Were you experiencing any symptoms then?
Patient: No, I was asymptomatic at that time.
Doctor: And the follow-up echocardiogram showed an increase in the size of the mass, causing RV outflow obstruction, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: After the discussion, you underwent another surgery to remove the mass, correct?
Patient: Yes, I did.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing your medical history with me. Based on this information, we will proceed with the heart transplant evaluation and determine the best course of action for you.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a candidate for heart transplant evaluation, reports a history of dyspnea and a holosystolic murmur detected at age 10, with a family history of cardiomyopathy (CM). Initial echocardiography revealed a 3.5 x 4.8 cm mass in the left atrium (LA), causing mitral regurgitation. The patient underwent tumor removal, confirmed as CM by pathology. At age 12, the patient presented with sudden abdominal and right leg pain, diagnosed with splenic infarction and femoral arterial embolism via CT, leading to splenectomy, embolectomy, and removal of multiple cardiac masses. At age 13, an asymptomatic right ventricular mass causing outflow obstruction was detected and subsequently removed.
O: Past medical interventions include midline sternotomy for tumor removal, splenectomy, embolectomy, and multiple cardiac surgeries for mass removal, all confirming CM. Recent echocardiograms have shown recurrent cardiac masses causing structural and functional heart issues. No physical signs of Carney complex were noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent cardiac myxoma (CM) with multiple interventions indicating aggressive or recurrent nature of the disease. Differential diagnosis could include other forms of cardiac tumors or systemic disease contributing to tumor genesis. The patient's history suggests a possible genetic predisposition to cardiac myxomas, complicating the prognosis and increasing the risk for further recurrences.
P: Proceed with a comprehensive heart transplant evaluation to assess suitability for transplantation given the recurrent nature of CM and its impact on cardiac function. Continue regular follow-up with cardiology for echocardiographic monitoring of potential tumor recurrence. Genetic consultation may be considered to evaluate for familial syndromes associated with myxomas. Educate the patient on signs of recurrence or complications and ensure adherence to follow-up schedules.

transcript:
Doctor: Hi, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been feeling something strange in my mouth since September 2015. There's a mass on my gums near my maxillary right canine and first premolar.
Doctor: I see. Let me do an examination to check it out. Hmm, I can see a 10 × 10-mm mass with elastic hardness and no mobility on the buccal gingiva at the maxillary right canine and first premolar region. There is partial redness of the surface mucosa, but it appears to be painless and non-pedunculated. 
Patient: Yes, that's exactly what I've been experiencing.
Doctor: I'd like to take a dental radiograph to get a better understanding of the issue. After reviewing the radiograph, I don't see any clear evidence of bone resorption at the maxillary right canine and first premolar region. Based on my findings, I am making a clinical diagnosis of epulis of the gingiva.
Patient: Oh, I see. So what's the next step?
Doctor: We'll need to remove the mass. I'm scheduling you for a resection under local anesthesia in November 2016. After the procedure, we'll have regular follow-ups to monitor your progress. 
Patient: Okay, thank you.
[After the surgical procedure and histopathological examination]
Doctor: Hi again, I wanted to update you on the results of the histopathological examination. The gingival growth was well delineated with a myxomatous stroma characterized by a sparsity of fibers. There was mild infiltration of plasma cells around the periphery of the blood vessels.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means the mass was a type of oral fibroma called OFM. The myxomatous stroma tested positive for Alcian blue, which is an indicator of this condition. It was negative for PAS, and no reticular fibers were identified on silver staining.
Patient: Will it come back?
Doctor: It's difficult to say for certain, but no recurrence was observed at your final follow-up, 1 year after the surgical procedure. We'll continue to monitor the area to ensure your health.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: The patient reported a mass on the gums near the maxillary right canine and first premolar since September 2015, describing it as painless with partial redness and no mobility.
O: Physical examination revealed a 10 × 10-mm mass with elastic hardness on the buccal gingiva at the maxillary right canine and first premolar region. Dental radiograph showed no evidence of bone resorption in the affected area. Histopathological examination post-resection identified the mass as an oral fibroma (OFM) with myxomatous stroma, positive for Alcian blue, negative for PAS, and no reticular fibers on silver staining.
A: The primary diagnosis is oral fibroma (OFM). Differential diagnosis initially included epulis of the gingiva, but was ruled out following histopathological findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with no recurrence observed one year post-surgery.
P: The management plan included surgical resection of the mass under local anesthesia, followed by regular follow-ups to monitor for recurrence. Continued observation and patient education on signs of recurrence are recommended.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you were referred to us in 2007 as a 34-year-old woman with IgA kappa multiple myeloma (MM), which was symptomatic for Anemia. Can you tell me more about your past medical history?
Patient: Oh, my past medical history was unremarkable before that.
Doctor: I understand that you were diagnosed after presenting to a dermatologist for a febrile rash with erythematoviolaceous nodules on your hands, forearms, and trunk. What did they find during the diagnostic process?
Patient: They did a bone marrow aspirate and found 50% infiltration by mature plasma cells. They also did a skin lesion biopsy.
Doctor: Yes, the biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of malignancy-associated Sweet's syndrome, according to the criteria proposed by Walker and Cohen's. So, you were started on PAD chemotherapy, which included bortezomib, doxorubicin, and dexamethasone. Due to the immunosuppression caused by MM and the concomitant treatment with dexamethasone, you were also given colchicine (1.5 g/die) for the treatment of the Sweet's syndrome. How did your body respond to the treatment?
Patient: The lesions disappeared after 10 days, and I continued the MM therapy.
Doctor: That's great to hear. I see that you later underwent peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC) mobilization with cyclophosphamide and received high-dose melphalan (MEL200) with PBSC transplantation in February 2008, achieving a very good partial response (VGPR). How have you been feeling since then?
Patient: I was doing well for a while, but in April 2011, the cutaneous rash came back, and my MM also recurred.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. It looks like you restarted colchicine and Lenalidomide-Dexamethasone to treat the recurrence. How has your body responded to the treatment this time?
Patient: It's been working well. The Sweet's Syndrome has been the first sign of relapse in all cases, but it always reverts under colchicine and salvage treatment for MM.
Doctor: It's good to know that the treatment has been effective in managing the Sweet's Syndrome and the MM relapses. It's important to keep a close eye on any signs of relapse and continue with the appropriate treatment. Make sure to attend regular follow-up appointments and inform your healthcare team of any changes in your symptoms.
Patient: Yes, I understand. I'll keep monitoring my symptoms and stay in touch with my healthcare team.
Doctor: That's great. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out to us. We're here to help you through this journey.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your support and guidance.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a 34-year-old woman diagnosed in 2007 with IgA kappa multiple myeloma (MM), initially presented with a febrile rash and erythematoviolaceous nodules on her hands, forearms, and trunk. Her past medical history was unremarkable before this. She reports that the skin lesions associated with Sweet's syndrome, a malignancy-associated condition, resolved after 10 days of treatment but recurred in April 2011 alongside MM. She notes that Sweet's Syndrome has been the first sign of MM relapse in all cases.
O: Initial diagnostic tests included a bone marrow aspirate showing 50% infiltration by mature plasma cells and a skin lesion biopsy confirming Sweet's syndrome. Treatment history includes PAD chemotherapy (bortezomib, doxorubicin, dexamethasone), colchicine (1.5 g/die), and high-dose melphalan with peripheral blood stem cell transplantation achieving a very good partial response (VGPR). On recurrence, she was treated with colchicine and Lenalidomide-Dexamethasone, to which she has responded well.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent IgA kappa multiple myeloma with associated Sweet's syndrome. The patient achieved VGPR post initial treatment but has experienced multiple relapses indicated by the recurrence of Sweet's syndrome. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the response to salvage therapies, though the recurrent nature of MM poses ongoing management challenges.
P: Continue current regimen of colchicine and Lenalidomide-Dexamethasone. Regular monitoring for signs of MM relapse and Sweet's syndrome is essential. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and modify the management plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms promptly. Encourage adherence to the treatment plan to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you have presented for an evaluation of your refractory anemia. Can you tell me about your medical history?
Patient: Sure, I was diagnosed with Felty syndrome when I was 64. I had rheumatoid arthritis, neutropenia, and an enlarged spleen.
Doctor: I see. And how was your anemia managed initially?
Patient: I was diagnosed with anemia of chronic disease after a complete examination, including a BM examination, which was negative for malignancy. I was given various therapeutic agents over time to control my rheumatoid arthritis, like adalimumab, methotrexate, abatacept, infliximab, azathioprine, rituximab, and prednisone.
Doctor: And did you undergo any surgery for your condition?
Patient: Yes, I had a splenectomy at 67 years old.
Doctor: How has your anemia progressed since then?
Patient: At 68, I became transfusion dependent. Later, I was diagnosed with myelodysplastic syndrome after another BM examination showed minimal morphologic dysplasia with a diploid karyotype.
Doctor: What treatments have you received for your myelodysplastic syndrome?
Patient: I was on erythropoietin support for a year, but my anemia worsened. Then, I was treated with adjusted-dose lenalidomide and my hemoglobin level reached 13 g/dL. But after 5 years, I lost the response and became transfusion dependent again.
Doctor: Did you receive any other treatments?
Patient: I was given one cycle of azacitidine, but it was discontinued after a BM examination showed no morphologic support for residual MDS. I continued to receive transfusions for nearly a year before coming here.
Doctor: Thank you for the information.
