We performed a BM core biopsy and aspiration, which demonstrated hypercellular marrow with trilineage dysplasia, moderate reticulin fibrosis, and 2% blasts (Fig. a, b). Flow cytometry showed changes consistent with MDS, including decreased side scatter in granulocytes (cytoplasmic hypogranularity), absence of hematogones, and a small number of aberrant myeloid blasts with an expression pattern of increased CD13 and CD34, and decreased CD38. Dendritic cells with a CD123bright, CD4+, HLA-DR+, CD56− immunophenotype were 0.2% of all analyzed cells (Fig. , top panel). Cytogenetic studies showed a normal diploid karyotype.
Patient: Okay, so what's the plan moving forward?
Doctor: We will discuss your case with a team of specialists and come up with the best course of action to manage your anemia and MDS. We will keep you informed and provide you with all the necessary information and support.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a 68-year-old with a history of Felty syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, neutropenia, and splenectomy, presents with refractory anemia. Initially diagnosed with anemia of chronic disease, the patient later developed myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and became transfusion dependent. Despite various treatments including erythropoietin and lenalidomide, the patient's anemia has worsened, leading to repeated transfusions.
O: Recent bone marrow (BM) core biopsy and aspiration revealed hypercellular marrow with trilineage dysplasia, moderate reticulin fibrosis, and 2% blasts. Flow cytometry indicated changes consistent with MDS, including decreased side scatter in granulocytes, absence of hematogones, and a small number of aberrant myeloid blasts with increased CD13 and CD34, and decreased CD38. Dendritic cells showed a CD123bright, CD4+, HLA-DR+, CD56− immunophenotype. Cytogenetic studies confirmed a normal diploid karyotype.
A: The primary diagnosis is refractory anemia secondary to myelodysplastic syndrome, complicated by a history of Felty syndrome and multiple treatments for rheumatoid arthritis. Differential diagnoses were considered and ruled out through BM examinations and flow cytometry.
P: The management plan includes consultation with a multidisciplinary team to discuss potential therapeutic options tailored to the patient's current clinical status and previous treatment responses. Continued transfusion support will be provided as needed, and the patient will be closely monitored for any progression or changes in their condition. Education regarding disease progression, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure the patient remains informed and engaged in their care plan.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you recently underwent resection of a part of your tongue due to tongue cancer. You've been admitted to our hospital for hepatocellular carcinoma. Can you tell me what symptoms you've been experiencing?
Patient: Yes, doctor. I've been feeling weak and I've noticed a lump in my abdomen.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. We found a tumor in your liver, about 5 cm in diameter, at liver segment IV. A computed tomography (CT) scan showed the tumor was enhanced during the arterial phase and washed out during the portal phase. It's pressing the right anterior branch to the main branch of Glisson and the middle hepatic vein. Based on these findings, we diagnosed you with hepatocellular carcinoma.
Patient: Oh no, that's not good.
Doctor: I understand this is concerning. We also tested your indocyanine green retention rate, which was 21.8%, and your Child-Pugh score is A. You tested negative for hepatitis B surface antigen and hepatitis C virus antibody, which is good news. However, you mentioned a history of excessive alcohol consumption, so we're considering the possibility of alcoholic liver damage.
Patient: Yeah, I used to drink quite a lot.
Doctor: To treat the hepatocellular carcinoma, we performed a partial hepatectomy with segments IV + V and a cholecystectomy with cystic duct-tube drainage. Intraoperative findings indicated that the anterior branch of the bile duct was exposed at the resected area, and some small bile ducts were ligated.
Patient: What happened after the surgery?
Doctor: On the first day following hepatectomy, bile leakage developed from the drain placed in the foramen of Winslow. CT showed fluid collection in the cavity between the liver and fistula to drain.
Patient: What did you do about it?
Doctor: We performed cholangiography via endoscopic bile duct enhancement, which showed no communication between the common bile duct and abdominal cavity. Then we conducted drip infusion cholangiography (DIC)-CT, which revealed the bile duct of the peripheral side. We decided to maintain simple drainage to reduce the cavity.
Patient: Did that work?
Doctor: On the 19th day after the surgery, you developed a fever and the CT revealed that the fluid collection had increased. We performed percutaneous drainage to the cavity near the liver cut surface.
Patient: And then?
Doctor: Cholangiography via the c-tube didn't show the anterior branch of the bile duct. Fistulogram from the drainage tube at the abdominal cavity showed the bile duct at segments V and VIII. Based on these findings, we diagnosed bile leakage from the isolated bile duct of segments V and VIII.
Patient: So, what's the plan now?
Doctor: We will need to implement further management to control the persistent biliary leak of 200-250 mL/day. We will closely monitor your condition and discuss the best course of action to ensure your recovery.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help in treating this.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports feeling weak and noticing a lump in his abdomen. He has a history of excessive alcohol consumption and a recent surgical history of tongue cancer resection.
O: The patient was diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segment IV, with a tumor size of 5 cm. CT imaging showed arterial enhancement and portal washout, pressing on the right anterior branch of Glisson and the middle hepatic vein. Indocyanine green retention rate was 21.8%, and Child-Pugh score is A. Tests for hepatitis B surface antigen and hepatitis C virus antibody were negative. Post-operative complications included bile leakage from the drain placed in the foramen of Winslow, with subsequent fluid collection near the liver cut surface. Cholangiography and DIC-CT confirmed bile leakage from the isolated bile duct of segments V and VIII.
A: Primary diagnosis is hepatocellular carcinoma with post-operative bile leakage from segments V and VIII. Differential diagnosis includes complications related to alcoholic liver damage. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with close monitoring and management of the bile leakage.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and persistent biliary leak of 200-250 mL/day. Further interventions to manage the bile leakage will be discussed. The patient will be educated on the importance of avoiding alcohol to prevent further liver damage. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you're here for an assessment due to a 2-week history of abdominal distension. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Have you ever had any past history of malignancy or any other significant medical events?
Patient: No, not really. I only had a cesarean section many years ago.
Doctor: I see. It appears that you had an endoscopic examination at a previous hospital, which revealed the presence of early carcinomas in your stomach and distal esophagus. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what they told me.
Doctor: Based on that, you were referred to our hospital for endoscopic resection. We've conducted a thorough examination and collected some laboratory data. Your serum carcinoembryonic antigen, squamous cell carcinoma antigen, and cytokeratin-19 fragment levels were all close to normal limits.
Patient: Oh, that's good to hear.
Doctor: During the endoscopic examination, we found mild granular elevated lesions with slightly depressed irregular mucosa in your distal esophagus. We also noticed a superficial elevated tumor-like lesion in the lower body of your stomach, with a diameter of about 10 mm.
Patient: Hmm, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We performed an endoscopic biopsy on the gastric lesion, and it was diagnosed as a well-differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma. As for the esophageal tumor, the biopsy showed intraepithelial tumor cells with atypical nuclei and prominent nucleoli.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: These histological findings suggest a malignant melanoma, invasive adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma, and Paget's disease as possible diagnoses. To further investigate, we performed immunohistochemical tests on the tumor cells.
Patient: What were the results?
Doctor: The tumor cells stained positive for CK7 and partially for CK20, but negative for S100 protein and HMB-47. All human mucin core proteins examined, such as MUC2, MUC5AC, and HIK1083, were also negative. Additionally, we observed p53 overexpression in all tumor cells.
Patient: So, what's the diagnosis?
Doctor: Based on these results, we can exclude malignant melanoma as a diagnosis. We have diagnosed the tumor as Paget's disease. We'll discuss further treatment options and follow-up requirements with you.
Patient: I see. Thank you for the explanation, doctor. I appreciate it.
soap_note:
S: The patient presents with a 2-week history of abdominal distension. No past history of malignancy, only a cesarean section many years ago. The patient reports a previous endoscopic examination showing early carcinomas in the stomach and distal esophagus.
O: Physical examination and recent endoscopic findings include mild granular elevated lesions with slightly depressed irregular mucosa in the distal esophagus and a superficial elevated tumor-like lesion in the lower body of the stomach, approximately 10 mm in diameter. Laboratory tests including serum carcinoembryonic antigen, squamous cell carcinoma antigen, and cytokeratin-19 fragment levels were near normal limits. Biopsy of the gastric lesion indicated well-differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma. Esophageal tumor biopsy showed intraepithelial tumor cells with atypical nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Immunohistochemical tests were positive for CK7 and partially for CK20, negative for S100 protein and HMB-47, with p53 overexpression in all tumor cells.
A: The patient is diagnosed with Paget's disease of the esophagus and well-differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma of the stomach. Differential diagnoses considered included malignant melanoma, invasive adenocarcinoma, and squamous cell carcinoma, which were largely excluded based on immunohistochemical results and histological findings.
P: The management plan will include discussing treatment options for Paget's disease and the gastric adenocarcinoma, which may involve further endoscopic resection or other oncological treatments as indicated. The patient will be scheduled for regular follow-up appointments to monitor the progression of the disease and response to treatment. Education regarding the nature of the diseases, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure patient understanding and compliance. Referral to oncology for specialized care will be arranged.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've been referred to our hospital due to an occasional finding during routine blood tests for monitoring your oral anticoagulant therapy. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I understand that you've been experiencing a weeklong history of fever, diarrhoea, and vomiting. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've had a fever up to 39 °C, and I've been having diarrhoea and vomiting for the past week.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Your medical history also includes chronic ischemic heart disease, valvular heart disease with a mitral valve replacement in 2001 using a mechanical prosthesis, permanent atrial fibrillation, arterial hypertension, chronic cerebrovascular disease, peripheral atherosclerosis of the lower extremities, stage 0 chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, stage IIIb chronic kidney disease, chronic gastritis, gastric resection for perforated gastric ulcer in 1975, cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis in 2009, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and bacterial pneumonia four months ago. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's all correct.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. At presentation, you were febrile with a temperature of 37.5 °C, and during the physical examination, we noticed abdominal distension, diffused tenderness, and bloating. Have you passed any stool since yesterday?
Patient: No, I haven't.
Doctor: We performed some blood tests and confirmed a severe prolongation of your prothrombin time (22.48), with normal liver function tests. We also noticed an increase in your C reactive protein (CRP) levels at 12.54 mg/dl, normal leucocyte and neutrophil count with mild lymphopenia (860/mm3) and monocytosis (1040/mm3), and acute kidney failure with a creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dl. There was no sign of acidosis or increased lactic acid levels.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Your chest X-ray showed mild pulmonary congestion. The abdominal X-ray revealed small intestine loop dilation and air-fluid levels, suggesting intestinal obstruction. An abdominal computed tomography confirmed these findings and also showed wall thickening of the terminal ileum. The radiologist said this could be compatible with either inflammatory bowel disease or intestinal ischemia. However, the general surgeon did not establish any surgical indication.
Patient: So, what does that mean?
Doctor: Considering your advanced age and the acute onset, we think it's unlikely that you have inflammatory bowel disease. Intestinal ischemia is also considered improbable due to the intestinal region involved (terminal ileus) and the normal lactate levels. We will continue to monitor your condition and develop a treatment plan accordingly.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me. What should I do next?
Doctor: We will admit you to the Department of Internal Medicine for further observation and treatment. Please follow the nurse's instructions for the admission process.
Patient: Okay, thank you doctor.
soap_note:
S: The patient, currently on oral anticoagulant therapy, presents with a weeklong history of fever, diarrhea, and vomiting. He reports a maximum temperature of 39 °C. His extensive medical history includes chronic ischemic heart disease, valvular heart disease with a mitral valve replacement, permanent atrial fibrillation, arterial hypertension, chronic cerebrovascular disease, peripheral atherosclerosis, stage 0 chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, stage IIIb chronic kidney disease, chronic gastritis, a history of gastric resection and cholecystectomy, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and a recent episode of bacterial pneumonia.
O: On examination, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 37.5 °C, exhibited abdominal distension, diffused tenderness, and bloating, and had not passed stool since the day before presentation. Blood tests showed severe prolongation of prothrombin time (22.48), normal liver function, elevated CRP (12.54 mg/dl), normal leucocyte and neutrophil count, mild lymphopenia (860/mm3), monocytosis (1040/mm3), and acute kidney failure (creatinine 1.7 mg/dl). Chest X-ray indicated mild pulmonary congestion. Abdominal X-ray and CT scan revealed small intestine loop dilation, air-fluid levels, and terminal ileum wall thickening, suggesting possible intestinal obstruction without surgical indication.
A: The primary assessment is non-surgical intestinal obstruction with differential diagnoses including inflammatory bowel disease and intestinal ischemia, though both are considered unlikely due to the patient's age, acute symptom onset, and specific intestinal findings. The severe prolongation of prothrombin time and elevated CRP suggest an inflammatory or infectious process, compounded by acute kidney failure.
P: The patient will be admitted to the Department of Internal Medicine for further observation and management. The treatment plan will include monitoring vital signs, fluid and electrolyte management, and adjustment of anticoagulant therapy to address the prolonged prothrombin time. Further diagnostic evaluations will be conducted to pinpoint the exact cause of the intestinal obstruction and address the acute kidney failure. Education will be provided regarding the importance of monitoring symptoms and medication compliance.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I presented at the clinic with some complaints. I've been experiencing a floater and a painless gradual decreased visual acuity in my right eye for the past 5 days.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any history of ocular surgery, trauma, systemic disease, or been on any medications?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those. But I did have ESWL for a 12-mm right renal pelvis stone about a week before these symptoms started.
Doctor: Okay, and how was your pre- and post-operative urine culture and urine analysis?
Patient: They were both negative and normal.
Doctor: Alright. Let's do a clinical examination to check your vision. *After examination* Your best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) for the right eye has decreased to 20/40 on the Snellen chart, while your left eye is at 20/20. Your intraocular pressure in both eyes is 15 mm/Hg. 
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: I also conducted a slit-lamp examination on your right eye and found conjunctival injection and +1 cell in the anterior chamber. The fundus examination showed clear media with +3 vitritis and an elevated white ball-like lesion with 1 disc diameter size, on para-fovea with a fluffy border. The right eye macular optical coherence tomography (OCT) displayed a hyper-reflective lesion in the vitreomacular interface as well.
Patient: What about my left eye?
Doctor: There were no remarkable signs in the examination of your left eye. I performed a diagnostic vitreous tap to take a sample for smear and culture. The smear of the vitreous sample with Giemsa stain showed multiple fungal spores with budding yeast and fungal pseudo-hypha and leukocyte infiltration.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: The cultures of the vitreous sample came back positive for Candida albicans after 7 days. This means you have a fungal infection in your right eye.
Patient: Oh no, what should I do?
Doctor: You'll be admitted to the hospital for treatment. We'll start with an intravitreal injection of amphotericin-B (5 μg/0.5 ml) and then prescribe topical atropine 1% Q6hr, topical prednisolone acetate 1% Q4hr, topical ciprofloxacin 0.3% Q6hr, intravenous amphotericin-B 1 mg/kg/day, and oral fluconazole 100 mg Q12hr. 
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: In addition to these treatments, we'll also perform a systemic workup including ANA, ANCA (P, C), AMA, and VDRL tests to ensure everything is in order.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll monitor your progress closely and make sure you receive the best possible care. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports experiencing a floater and a painless, gradual decrease in visual acuity in the right eye over the past 5 days. The patient denies any history of ocular surgery, trauma, systemic disease, or medication use. However, the patient underwent extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) for a 12-mm right renal pelvis stone approximately one week prior to symptom onset.
O: Clinical examination revealed a best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of 20/40 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. Intraocular pressure was normal at 15 mmHg in both eyes. Slit-lamp examination of the right eye showed conjunctival injection and +1 cell in the anterior chamber. Fundus examination indicated +3 vitritis and an elevated white ball-like lesion with a fluffy border on the para-fovea. Macular optical coherence tomography (OCT) of the right eye displayed a hyper-reflective lesion at the vitreomacular interface. Diagnostic vitreous tap and Giemsa stain of the right eye revealed multiple fungal spores with budding yeast, fungal pseudo-hypha, and leukocyte infiltration. Cultures confirmed Candida albicans infection.
A: The primary diagnosis is fungal endophthalmitis in the right eye, specifically due to Candida albicans. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vitritis or infectious endophthalmitis, but these are less likely given the culture results and clinical findings.
P: The patient will be admitted to the hospital for immediate treatment, which includes an intravitreal injection of amphotericin-B (5 μg/0.5 ml) and administration of topical atropine 1% every 6 hours, topical prednisolone acetate 1% every 4 hours, topical ciprofloxacin 0.3% every 6 hours, intravenous amphotericin-B 1 mg/kg/day, and oral fluconazole 100 mg every 12 hours. A systemic workup including ANA, ANCA (P, C), AMA, and VDRL tests will be performed to rule out systemic involvement. The patient will be closely monitored for response to treatment and potential complications, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. Education regarding the importance of adherence to the prescribed therapy and follow-up appointments will be provided.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you presented with metamorphopsia in your left eye back in September 2013. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yeah, I started noticing some distortion in my vision in my left eye, and it worried me a bit.
Doctor: I understand. According to your records, you were diagnosed with a vitreomacular traction (VMT) with an adhesion diameter of 397 μm and a macular cyst in your left eye. Your right eye did not show any pathology at that time. You were a myopic patient, and your initial best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 1.0 with a foveal thickness of 335 μm.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: It looks like you received an intravitreal C3F8 gas injection of 0.3 ml in your left eye about 3 weeks after the diagnosis. The VMT release occurred 173 days after the injection, with a foveal thickness of 205 μm and a consistent BCVA. No macular cyst was detectable on SD-OCT after resolution.
Patient: Yes, I remember that. My vision improved after the treatment.
Doctor: Now, in December 2014, when you were 51 years old, it appears that you were diagnosed with a VMT with an adhesion diameter of 397 μm in your right eye. At presentation, your BCVA was 1.0, and the foveal thickness was 351 μm. Can you tell me how you felt at that time?
Patient: I was concerned about my right eye because I had already experienced the issue with my left eye.
Doctor: After 54 days of observation, your BCVA in the right eye decreased to 0.5. It seems that you received a 0.3-ml intravitreal C3F8 gas injection in your right eye as a treatment. Do you recall that?
Patient: Yes, I do. I had the same treatment as I did for my left eye.
Doctor: Three weeks after the injection, the vitreous body detached from the retina in your right eye. Subsequently, your BCVA improved to 1.0 again, and the foveal thickness was 204 μm. How has your vision been since then?
Patient: My vision has been much better since the treatment. I'm grateful for the care I received.
Doctor: That's great to hear. It's important to continue monitoring your eye health and attending regular check-ups. If you notice any changes in your vision or have any concerns, please don't hesitate to contact us.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I'll make sure to keep an eye on my vision and schedule regular check-ups.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care and have a great day!
Patient: You too, thanks!
soap_note:
S: The patient reported initial symptoms of vision distortion in the left eye, diagnosed as vitreomacular traction (VMT) with associated macular cyst. The patient experienced similar symptoms later in the right eye. Both instances were concerning to the patient, who has a history of myopia.
O: Initial diagnosis of VMT in the left eye showed an adhesion diameter of 397 μm and a foveal thickness of 335 μm. Post-treatment with 0.3 ml intravitreal C3F8 gas, VMT released with improved foveal thickness to 205 μm and stable BCVA. In the right eye, diagnosed with VMT (adhesion diameter 397 μm, initial foveal thickness 351 μm), post-treatment foveal thickness improved to 204 μm with restored BCVA to 1.0.
A: The patient was successfully treated for VMT in both eyes with intravitreal C3F8 gas injections. The resolution of macular cysts and improvement in foveal thickness and BCVA post-treatment confirm effective management of VMT. No current signs of recurrence or other complications are evident.
P: Continue regular ophthalmologic check-ups to monitor for any changes in vision or potential recurrence of VMT. Educate the patient on symptoms of potential eye health issues to ensure prompt treatment. Encourage adherence to follow-up schedules to maintain eye health and prevent complications.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I'm a 49-year-old male and I've been experiencing a sudden onset of severe, left-sided abdominal pain radiating to the groin for one day.
Doctor: I see. Are you a smoker or do you have any significant past medical or surgical history?
Patient: No, I'm a nonsmoker and I don't have any significant medical or surgical history.
Doctor: Okay. How about your family history? Any known medical conditions in your family?
Patient: Yes, my brother has factor V Leiden mutation, and my half-sister has factor XII deficiency.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Let's first check your vital signs. *After checking vital signs* Your vitals show you're afebrile, with a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg, pulse at 55/min, and a respiratory rate of 22/min. I'm now going to perform a physical examination. *After examination* You have generalized abdominal pain on palpation. We'll need to do a computed tomography (CT) scan of your abdomen and pelvis to get a better understanding of what's going on.
Patient: Okay, sounds good.
*After CT scan*
Doctor: The CT scan results show poor opacification of the upper and interpolar segments of your left kidney, which could be concerning for a renal infarct. To rule out an embolic source, we'll perform a transthoracic echocardiography.
Patient: Alright, let's do it.
*After echocardiography*
Doctor: The echocardiography showed no evidence of a thrombus in your heart. To further delineate the underlying pathology and for revascularization, we'll plan a renal artery angiography.
Patient: Okay, when will that be done?
Doctor: We'll schedule it as soon as possible. *After angiography* The angiography showed FMD with a clot in the anterior branch of your left renal artery. We're going to start you on apixaban for the clot and amlodipine for your hypertension.
Patient: Got it, thank you.
*In the outpatient setting*
Doctor: Your recent renal artery duplex showed 0-59% stenosis of the left renal artery. Carotid and abdominal visceral arterial ultrasounds were unremarkable. After one month of therapy, we'll discontinue apixaban since you're asymptomatic and your blood pressure is now 120/82 mmHg. Over the next six months, you'll undergo repeat imaging with a CT angiography (CTA) of the abdominal vasculature.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
*After six months*
Doctor: Your recent CTA showed resolution of the clot and a beading pattern suggestive of FMD. We'll continue to monitor your condition and adjust your treatment as needed.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: A 49-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of severe, left-sided abdominal pain radiating to the groin, lasting for one day. He denies any significant personal medical or surgical history. Family history includes a brother with factor V Leiden mutation and a half-sister with factor XII deficiency. He is a nonsmoker.
O: Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg, pulse 55/min, respiratory rate 22/min, and afebrile status. Physical examination shows generalized abdominal pain on palpation. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis indicates poor opacification of the upper and interpolar segments of the left kidney, suggestive of a renal infarct. Echocardiography shows no evidence of a thrombus in the heart. Renal artery angiography reveals fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) with a clot in the anterior branch of the left renal artery. Follow-up renal artery duplex shows 0-59% stenosis of the left renal artery, and carotid and abdominal visceral arterial ultrasounds are unremarkable. Recent CT angiography shows resolution of the clot and a beading pattern indicative of FMD.
A: The primary diagnosis is renal infarct secondary to FMD with a clot in the left renal artery. Differential diagnoses initially included embolic sources from the heart, which were ruled out with echocardiography. The patient's hypertension is likely secondary to renal artery stenosis.
P: Initiated treatment with apixaban for the clot and amlodipine for hypertension. Plan to discontinue apixaban after one month due to asymptomatic status and controlled blood pressure, which is now 120/82 mmHg. Continue monitoring with repeat imaging using CT angiography of the abdominal vasculature over the next six months. Adjust treatment as necessary based on imaging results and clinical status. Educate the patient on the importance of compliance with medication and follow-up appointments to manage his condition effectively.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith from the Orthopedic Surgery Department. Our study on your son has been approved by the Ethics Committee and the Pediatric Orthopedic Clinic at Imam Khomeini Hospital. Thank you for signing the consent form. I understand you referred your son to us due to concerns about the increasing severity of his disease, despite regular occupational therapy. Is that correct?
Patient's Mother: Yes, doctor. We've been very concerned about his condition and haven't seen much improvement with the therapy.
Doctor: I see. In the physical examination, your son was found to be developmentally delayed, unable to walk or stand, and showed cognitional and motor retardation. We also noticed flexion contractures in his elbows, wrists, knees, and hips. There is bilateral equinovarus deformity of his feet and an increased popliteal angle. His plantar reflexes showed an extension response, and his DTRs were exaggerated. We recorded a spastic response in his muscles after continuous stretching. Also, his sitting balance is extremely unstable. Have you noticed these symptoms before?
Patient's Mother: Yes, doctor. We've observed these issues, but we didn't know what they meant.
Doctor: I understand. It's important to know that your son was born as a result of a consanguine marriage and had a normal pregnancy. His birth weight was 2950 grams, and his head circumference and height were 35 and 47, respectively. He showed normal weight gaining and development during the first few months of his life. He was able to hold his head at 5 months and roll over at 7 months. Do you remember when you were first told about the possibility of an abnormality?
Patient's Mother: Yes, it was during a routine screening at 5 months of age when the pediatrician noticed a decreased head circumference growth.
Doctor: That's correct. Further investigation showed that his head circumference reached a plateau of 40 cm around 12 months of age. Since then, his general and developmental condition seemed to experience a sudden pause with progressive delay in growth and development. He lost his ability to roll over and never gained any gross motor milestones. His face became expressionless, and his eyes started to sink into the orbits. Other findings include apparent cachectic dwarfism, microcephaly, and pigmented retinopathy. Are you familiar with these conditions?
Patient's Mother: We've heard of some of them, but not all. It's been very overwhelming for us.
Doctor: I understand this can be difficult for you and your family. It's essential to keep up with his occupational therapy and follow up with us regularly to monitor his progress and adjust his treatment plan as needed. We'll work together to provide the best care for your son.
Patient's Mother: Thank you, doctor. We appreciate your help and guidance.
soap_note:
S: The patient's mother reports increasing severity of her son's condition despite regular occupational therapy. She has observed symptoms such as inability to walk or stand, and unstable sitting balance, but was unaware of their medical implications. The patient was born from a consanguineous marriage, had normal early development, but showed signs of developmental delay starting from around 5 months, with a significant decline noted after 12 months.
O: Physical examination revealed developmental delay, inability to walk or stand, cognitional and motor retardation, flexion contractures in elbows, wrists, knees, and hips, bilateral equinovarus deformity, increased popliteal angle, extensor plantar reflexes, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (DTRs), and spastic muscle response to stretching. The patient also exhibits cachectic dwarfism, microcephaly, and pigmented retinopathy. His birth weight was 2950 grams, with initial normal head circumference and height. Head circumference growth decreased noticeably by 5 months and plateaued at 40 cm by 12 months.
A: The patient presents with severe developmental delay, motor and cognitive impairments, and physical deformities likely related to an underlying genetic or neurological condition, exacerbated by consanguinity. Differential diagnoses could include cerebral palsy, genetic syndromes, or metabolic disorders. The prognosis depends on the specific underlying diagnosis but is concerning given the progressive nature of symptoms and developmental regression.
P: Continue regular occupational therapy and schedule frequent follow-ups in our clinic to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Genetic counseling and further diagnostic workup including genetic testing and metabolic screening are recommended to clarify the diagnosis and guide management. Educate the family about the nature of the patient's condition, potential outcomes, and the importance of regular medical care.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello there! I see that you're a 4-year-old girl with cystic fibrosis, pancreatic insufficiency, and chronic pulmonary colonization by Gram-positive bacteria. You were admitted to our hospital for a pulmonary exacerbation, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Based on your last available sputum culture, we started intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam (150 mg/kg/day in three doses) and tobramycin (10 mg/kg in one dose), and you've shown progressive clinical improvement since then. During your hospitalization, we've also continued your daily treatment, including physiotherapy, an inhaled long-acting beta-agonist, and oral pancreatic enzymes. Is that right?
Patient: Yes, that's what I've been doing.
Doctor: However, after 14 days of treatment, you presented with a high-grade fever, up to 40 °C, and a diffuse maculopapular erythaematous rash involving your trunk and eventually your whole body. Have you also developed generalized polyadenomegaly and hepatomegaly?
Patient: Yes, I have.
Doctor: Your laboratory investigations showed a rise in CRP levels (10.31 mg/dL, normal value: < 0.5 mg/dL) and a progressive increase in serum transaminase levels, with aspartate aminotransferase and alanine aminotransferase levels > 40 U/L and > 10 times the upper limit of normal, respectively. Coagulation tests also revealed very high d-dimer concentrations (68,340 ng/mL, normal value: < 230 ng/mL), a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time ratio (1.94, normal value: 0.86–1.20) and an INR of 1.23 (normal value: 0.94–1.22). Your LDH concentrations increased to 10,880 U/L at 4 days after the onset of symptoms. Did you know that your autoimmune, infective, and haematologic tests were negative?
Patient: No, I didn't know that.
Doctor: We also noticed a parallel progressive increase in your eosinophil count, reaching a maximum absolute value of 2940/mmc on the 18th day. Based on a RegiSCAR total score of 6, we've established a diagnosis of DRESS syndrome. As a result, we've stopped your antibiotic treatment.
Patient: And what does that mean for me?
Doctor: Without any further therapy, we expect a progressive resolution of your clinical features. We'll continue to monitor your condition closely and provide the necessary care to help you recover.
Patient: Thank you, doctor.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a 4-year-old girl with cystic fibrosis, pancreatic insufficiency, and chronic pulmonary colonization by Gram-positive bacteria, was admitted for a pulmonary exacerbation. She reported progressive clinical improvement with intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam and tobramycin, along with ongoing daily treatments including physiotherapy, an inhaled long-acting beta-agonist, and oral pancreatic enzymes. However, after 14 days of treatment, she developed a high-grade fever of 40 °C, a diffuse maculopapular erythematous rash, generalized polyadenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.
O: The patient's laboratory investigations revealed elevated CRP levels at 10.31 mg/dL, significantly increased serum transaminase levels (AST and ALT > 10 times the upper limit of normal), very high d-dimer concentrations at 68,340 ng/mL, a prolonged aPTT ratio of 1.94, and an INR of 1.23. LDH concentrations were also elevated to 10,880 U/L. Autoimmune, infective, and hematologic tests were negative. Eosinophil count reached a maximum of 2940/mmc on the 18th day.
A: The primary diagnosis is DRESS syndrome, indicated by a RegiSCAR total score of 6, following the administration of antibiotics. The differential diagnosis initially included other causes of fever and rash but was ruled out by negative autoimmune, infective, and hematologic tests.
P: The antibiotic treatment was discontinued due to the diagnosis of DRESS syndrome. The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with supportive care to manage symptoms and prevent complications. The expected outcome is a progressive resolution of clinical features without further specific therapy. Regular follow-ups will be necessary to assess recovery and manage ongoing cystic fibrosis care.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've come to consult about your recent symptoms. Can you tell me more about your history and what you've been experiencing?
Patient: Well, I've been feeling disoriented and sleepy for about two weeks. It got worse and I became so stuporous that I needed invasive mechanical ventilation.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Have you had any major surgeries or medical events recently?
Patient: Yes, I had a Cesarean section four months ago, but there were no complications during my pregnancy or delivery.
Doctor: Alright, thank you for that information. When you were admitted to the emergency room, we performed a physical exam and found the presence of jaundice and hepatomegaly, but no clinical signs suggesting cirrhosis.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We also conducted laboratory tests which registered an altered liver profile and elevated ammonia levels at 595.7 umol/L. This prompted us to perform an abdominal tomography.
Patient: What did the tomography show?
Doctor: The tomography reported a liver lesion that was initially interpreted as a hepatic adenoma. We then carried out abdominal magnetic resonance imaging, which showed results compatible with fibrolamellar hepatocarcinoma. There were no signs of cirrhosis or portal hypertension.
Patient: That sounds concerning.
Doctor: Yes, it is a serious condition. In light of your neurological symptoms, we also performed a simple head tomography which showed unspecific periventricular lesions. A lumbar puncture ruled out infectious involvement, and telemetry reported moderate encephalopathy without seizure activity.
Patient: So, what's causing the encephalopathy?
Doctor: We initially thought it might be hyperammonemic encephalopathy caused by urea metabolism disorders. However, tests for urinary orotic acid levels, serum amino acids, and serum citrulline levels all came back normal.
Patient: What does that mean then?
Doctor: Given the lack of an etiology for the hyperammonemic encephalopathy and the findings suggestive of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma, we performed a liver biopsy. The immunohistochemistry confirmed the diagnosis. There was weak expression for glutamine synthetase, while glypican 3 and amyloid A were negative. The expression for B-catenin was membrane, without aberrant expression. The cell proliferation index determined with KI 67 was 5%. This pattern favors a diagnosis of fibrolamellar variant hepatocellular carcinoma.
Patient: Are there any other areas in my body affected by this?
Doctor: We conducted extension studies which ruled out metastatic bone or chest involvement, and we found no neoplastic lesions elsewhere in your body.
Patient: That's a relief. What's the next step?
Doctor: We will discuss your case with a multidisciplinary team and determine the best course of action for treatment. We'll keep you informed and make sure you receive the necessary care and support.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a postpartum female, reports experiencing disorientation and sleepiness for two weeks, worsening to stupor requiring invasive mechanical ventilation. She had a Cesarean section four months ago without complications.
O: Physical examination revealed jaundice and hepatomegaly, but no signs of cirrhosis. Laboratory tests showed altered liver profile and elevated ammonia levels at 595.7 umol/L. Abdominal tomography indicated a liver lesion initially thought to be hepatic adenoma, but MRI findings were compatible with fibrolamellar hepatocarcinoma. Head tomography showed unspecific periventricular lesions. Lumbar puncture and telemetry ruled out infectious causes and seizure activity, respectively. Liver biopsy confirmed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma with specific immunohistochemistry markers and a cell proliferation index of 5%. Extension studies ruled out metastatic involvement in bone or chest.
A: The primary diagnosis is fibrolamellar variant hepatocellular carcinoma, complicated by hyperammonemic encephalopathy. Differential diagnosis initially included urea cycle disorders, but was ruled out by normal urinary orotic acid, serum amino acids, and citrulline levels.
P: The patient's case will be discussed with a multidisciplinary team to determine the optimal treatment strategy. Ongoing monitoring of liver function and neurological status is necessary. Patient education regarding the diagnosis, treatment options, and prognosis will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to oncology for further management and potential surgical intervention is planned.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented to the ED six hours after your lithotripsy and laser stone ablation for left ureterolithiasis. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having this sudden onset of non-radiating, left-sided aching abdominal pain for about one hour now. It's also associated with mild nausea and left arm pain.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. How would you describe the pain in your arm?
Patient: It's an aching, throbbing sensation. The discomfort is pretty severe.
Doctor: Have you taken any medication for the pain?
Patient: Yes, I took a hydrocodone/acetaminophen 5/325 mg tablet when the symptoms started, but the pain hasn't changed.
Doctor: Have you experienced any fever, chills, shortness of breath, or chest pain?
Patient: No, I haven't.
Doctor: Can you tell me about your past medical and surgical history?
Patient: I've had kidney stones before. I also had a cesarean section and the recent stone ablation and ureteral stenting you mentioned.
Doctor: What medications are you currently taking?
Patient: Just the hydrocodone 5/325mg tablets prescribed post-operatively.
Doctor: Do you smoke, use illicit drugs, or drink alcohol?
Patient: I don't smoke or use drugs, but I do have an occasional alcoholic beverage.
Doctor: Alright, let me perform a physical exam. *Examines patient* You appear to be overweight, and your vital signs show an oral temperature of 97.6°F, heart rate of 92 bpm, respirations of 22 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 93/60 mmHg. I'm noticing pallor of your left distal forearm with no palpable radial or ulnar pulses, slightly delayed capillary refill to the fingers of your left hand, and diminished bowel sounds in your abdomen. There's also some mild left costovertebral angle tenderness. 
Patient: Hmm, that doesn't sound too good.
Doctor: Based on your symptoms, I'm considering a few possible diagnoses: arterial occlusion of the left arm, sepsis secondary to urinary tract infection or pyelonephritis, local peritonitis from ureteral rupture, mesenteric ischemia, and abdominal organ injury from lithotripsy. We'll need to do some further tests to confirm.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: I'm going to involve vascular surgery in your care. In the meantime, please follow any instructions given and let us know if your symptoms worsen.
Patient: Alright, thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: Patient reports sudden onset of non-radiating, left-sided aching abdominal pain for about one hour, associated with mild nausea and left arm pain described as aching and throbbing. The pain severity is high, and it has not responded to hydrocodone/acetaminophen 5/325 mg taken at symptom onset. No fever, chills, shortness of breath, or chest pain reported. Past medical history includes recurrent kidney stones, cesarean section, and recent left ureterolithiasis treated with lithotripsy and ureteral stenting. No history of smoking or illicit drug use; occasional alcohol consumption.
O: Physical examination reveals the patient is overweight. Vital signs: oral temperature 97.6°F, heart rate 92 bpm, respirations 22/min, blood pressure 93/60 mmHg. Notable findings include pallor and absence of palpable pulses in the left distal forearm, delayed capillary refill in the left hand, diminished bowel sounds, and mild left costovertebral angle tenderness.
A: Differential diagnoses include arterial occlusion of the left arm, potential sepsis secondary to urinary tract infection or pyelonephritis, local peritonitis from possible ureteral rupture, mesenteric ischemia, and abdominal organ injury post-lithotripsy. The primary concern is arterial occlusion given the absence of pulses and pallor in the left arm.
P: Immediate referral to vascular surgery for evaluation of the left arm. Continue monitoring vital signs and symptoms. Maintain hydration and continue pain management with hydrocodone/acetaminophen as prescribed, adjusting dosage as needed based on further evaluation. Further diagnostic tests, including Doppler ultrasound of the left arm, abdominal ultrasound, and possibly CT abdomen, are necessary to evaluate the extent of suspected complications. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and the importance of prompt reporting.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having some complaints like intermittent palpitation and shortness of breath for the past 6 months.
Doctor: I see. Let's start with a physical examination. Hmm, everything seems unremarkable. I would suggest you get an echocardiography done.
Patient: Alright, I got the echocardiography done, and they found an ASD with a diameter of 10 mm.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. I'd also like you to undergo an enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan to investigate further.
Patient: Okay, I did the CT scan, and it demonstrated a huge cystic mass in my left superior anterior mediastinum, close to the pulmonary trunk. They showed me some images, like Fig. a and b.
Doctor: I see. Did they find any significant artery feeding the mass?
Patient: No, they didn't find any significant artery feeding it.
Doctor: Alright. Your cancer antigen 125 levels are also higher than normal. Based on your test results, the preoperative diagnosis is cystic teratoma. We will perform a uniportal video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery to address this issue.
Patient: I had the surgery, and during the operation, the doctor found something unusual. They said it was a completely CAP.
Doctor: Interesting. It seems that a large cystic lesion (9 cm × 9 cm × 10 cm) was visualized, bulging through the aortopulmonary window. They must have performed a mini-incision to the cystic lesion and removed a white viscous liquid.
Patient: Yes, that's what they did. They also separated the basal segment of the mass from the mediastinal pleura.
Doctor: Good. It seems they didn't perform any surgical intervention for the CAP and ASD. The histopathology results revealed that the lesion had a smooth inner wall with gray gelatinous material, and under the microscope, they could see cystic dilated bronchus, lung tissue, and its own pleura.
Patient: So, what's the final diagnosis?
Doctor: The final diagnosis is ELS, not cystic teratoma. We reassessed the enhanced CT, but still couldn't find a significant feeding artery for ELS.
Patient: How am I doing now?
Doctor: Your recovery has been excellent. During your follow-up, you're in great condition with no more intermittent palpitation and shortness of breath.
Patient: That's a relief! Thank you, doctor, for your help.
soap_note:
S: The patient reported experiencing intermittent palpitations and shortness of breath for the past 6 months. The patient underwent echocardiography, revealing an atrial septal defect (ASD) with a diameter of 10 mm. Subsequent enhanced CT scan showed a large cystic mass in the left superior anterior mediastinum, close to the pulmonary trunk, without a significant feeding artery. The patient underwent uniportal video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery, during which a cystic lesion was identified and managed.
O: Physical examination was unremarkable. Echocardiography identified a 10 mm ASD. CT scan demonstrated a large cystic mass in the mediastinum. Cancer antigen 125 levels were elevated. Surgical findings included a cystic lesion measuring 9 cm x 9 cm x 10 cm, from which a white viscous liquid was extracted. Histopathology revealed a smooth inner wall with gray gelatinous material, cystic dilated bronchus, lung tissue, and its own pleura.
A: The final diagnosis is extralobar sequestration (ELS), initially suspected to be cystic teratoma. The presence of an ASD was also noted. The patient's symptoms of palpitations and shortness of breath have resolved postoperatively.
P: The patient underwent successful uniportal video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery to remove the cystic mass. No surgical intervention was performed for the ASD at this time. Follow-up care includes monitoring the ASD and assessing for any potential complications. The patient's recovery has been excellent, with resolution of initial symptoms. Further follow-up is necessary to monitor the patient's cardiac status and ensure no recurrence of ELS or progression of ASD.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented to our emergency department with a three-week history of productive cough, rhinorrhea, non-bloody non-bilious emesis, and intermittent fevers with a maximum temperature of 102 °F. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yes, my daughter has had a cough and runny nose for a few weeks now, and she's been vomiting sometimes too. She's also had some fevers.
Doctor: I understand. In her medical history, I see that she has been treated for pneumonia twice in the past six months and has a history of recurrent ear infections. She was also diagnosed with moderate persistent asthma a year ago. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Okay, and her birth history was uncomplicated, with no structural heart disease or other congenital defects, correct?
Patient: Yes, everything was fine when she was born.
Doctor: Good to know. She's up to date with her vaccines, including four doses of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV)13, right?
Patient: Yes, she's had all her vaccines.
Doctor: And there's no family history of recurrent infections, immunodeficiency, consanguinity, or cardiac problems, correct?
Patient: No, none of that.
Doctor: During the physical exam, we noted subcostal retractions, crackles, and decreased air entry on her right side. In light of her respiratory distress, we obtained a chest radiograph, which demonstrated an opacification in her right lower lobe. So, we admitted her with a diagnosis of pneumonia.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: The following morning, we detected a new soft 2/6 systolic murmur over her cardiac apex. We performed a cardiac echocardiography, which revealed a 3-mm vegetation on the anterior mitral valve leaflet.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It's an indication of an infection in her heart. Her initial laboratory evaluation showed a white count of 23 x 10^3/cu.mm3, with 83.4% neutrophils. Her C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) were 131.17 mg/dL and 35 mm/hr, respectively. We also tested her for Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which came back negative.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: The primary blood culture grew Streptococcus pneumoniae, serotype 3N, which is sensitive to penicillin G and ceftriaxone. Based on the clinical findings of a new murmur, cardiac vegetations on the echocardiogram, and the blood culture report, we diagnosed her with infective endocarditis (IE).
Patient: How will you treat it?
Doctor: We'll treat her with IV ceftriaxone for four weeks. We'll also closely monitor her CBC and CRP levels throughout her hospital stay until her leukocytosis resolves and her CRP normalizes.
Patient: I understand. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll do a follow-up echocardiogram as well. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more questions or concerns.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a young child, presented with a three-week history of productive cough, rhinorrhea, non-bloody non-bilious emesis, and intermittent fevers peaking at 102 °F. She has a past medical history of recurrent pneumonia, recurrent ear infections, and moderate persistent asthma. She is up-to-date with vaccinations, including PCV13, and has no family history of recurrent infections, immunodeficiency, or cardiac issues.
O: Physical examination revealed subcostal retractions, crackles, and decreased air entry on the right side. A chest radiograph showed opacification in the right lower lobe. Cardiac echocardiography detected a 3-mm vegetation on the anterior mitral valve leaflet. Laboratory findings included a white blood cell count of 23 x 10^3/cu.mm3 with 83.4% neutrophils, CRP of 131.17 mg/dL, and ESR of 35 mm/hr. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus pneumoniae, serotype 3N, sensitive to penicillin G and ceftriaxone. HIV test was negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is infective endocarditis (IE), secondary to Streptococcus pneumoniae, with underlying pneumonia. The presence of cardiac vegetation and elevated inflammatory markers support this diagnosis. Differential diagnoses could include other sources of infection or complications from her known asthma.
P: The treatment plan includes administering IV ceftriaxone for four weeks. Monitoring will include regular CBC and CRP levels to track resolution of leukocytosis and normalization of CRP. A follow-up echocardiogram is scheduled to assess the cardiac vegetation. The patient will remain hospitalized during the initial phase of treatment to ensure stability and effective response to antibiotics.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 38-year-old woman who has been pregnant 5 times and have delivered 3 healthy children via lower segment CSs 15, 11, and 8 years ago, respectively. What brings you here today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I'm currently 32+1 weeks pregnant, and I came to the emergency department because I've been experiencing some spotting.
Doctor: I see. Have you registered your current pregnancy with any hospital or received any antenatal care?
Patient: No, I haven't registered with any hospital, and I haven't received any antenatal care.
Doctor: Okay. Have you noticed any other symptoms or issues during your pregnancy?
Patient: Between 28 and 30 weeks of gestation, I had intermittent minor spotting, but I didn't go to any hospital or receive any treatment for it.
Doctor: I understand. We've conducted some tests and found that your hemoglobin (HGB) concentration is 87 g/L. We also performed an ultrasonography, which revealed that the lower edge of the placenta is completely covering the internal cervical orifice, and there is a suspicion of the presence of a pernicious placenta previa (PPP).
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What does that mean?
Doctor: It means there might be a risk of severe bleeding as your pregnancy progresses. We also conducted a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) which confirmed that you have pernicious placenta previa, as well as placenta accreta and placenta percreta on the lower anterior uterine wall. We could see distended and twisted vessels on the surface of the lower anterior uterine wall.
Patient: What will happen now?
Doctor: You will be admitted to the obstetric ward, and we'll treat you with dexamethasone to promote pulmonary maturation in the baby. We will closely monitor your condition.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: At 33 weeks gestation, you experienced 450 mL of vaginal bleeding, and we immediately transferred you to the operation room for emergency CS. Your blood pressure was 125/75 mm Hg, and your heart rate was 90 beats/min upon arrival.
Patient: What happened next?
Doctor: A resuscitation team, including senior staff from the departments of gynecology, obstetrics, anesthesiology, neonatology, the ICU, blood bank, laboratories, and a nursing team, was immediately established. The anesthesiologist punctured an artery for invasive blood pressure monitoring, and devices for autologous blood recovery were assembled. Nurses also established four 16 G intravenous lines for fluid infusion.
Patient: I'm glad everything was in place. How is my baby doing?
Doctor: The baby is doing well, and we'll continue to monitor both of you closely. It's important to follow up with your healthcare provider for any future pregnancies and receive appropriate antenatal care to minimize risks.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate all the care and attention I've received.
soap_note:
S: The patient is a 38-year-old woman, G5P3, currently 32+1 weeks pregnant, presenting with complaints of spotting. She reported intermittent minor spotting between 28 and 30 weeks of gestation but did not seek medical attention. The patient has not registered this pregnancy with a hospital nor received any antenatal care.
O: The patient's hemoglobin level is 87 g/L (normal range: 120-160 g/L). Ultrasonography and MRI findings indicate the presence of pernicious placenta previa, placenta accreta, and placenta percreta on the lower anterior uterine wall, with distended and twisted vessels noted. At 33 weeks gestation, she experienced significant vaginal bleeding (450 mL) and underwent an emergency cesarean section. Vital signs at the time of surgery were blood pressure 125/75 mm Hg and heart rate 90 beats/min.
A: The primary diagnosis is pernicious placenta previa complicated by placenta accreta and placenta percreta. The patient's history of multiple cesarean sections likely contributed to the development of these conditions. The significant vaginal bleeding she experienced posed a high risk to both maternal and fetal health.
P: The patient was treated with dexamethasone to promote fetal lung maturity and underwent an emergency cesarean section due to acute bleeding. Postoperative management included close monitoring in the obstetric ward with multidisciplinary team involvement. The patient and her newborn are to be closely monitored, and she is advised to register future pregnancies early and engage in regular antenatal care to manage and mitigate potential risks. Follow-up appointments with obstetrics and possibly maternal-fetal medicine are recommended to assess recovery and plan for future care.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, can you tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: I don't really have any significant past medical history.
Doctor: Alright. Can you describe the symptoms you're experiencing?
Patient: I've had this altered mental status for 3 days, along with flu-like symptoms, a severe headache, and pancytopenia.
Doctor: I see. Let's conduct a physical examination. Hmm, there seems to be mild neck stiffness, but the rest of the examination is unremarkable. We'll need to do some lab tests to figure out what's going on.
Patient: Okay, doc.
Doctor: Your laboratory tests show abnormalities, particularly pancytopenia. We'll need to perform a lumbar puncture and start you on empiric antibiotics along with acyclovir.
Patient: Alright, if that's what you think is best.
Doctor: The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows elevated white blood cells with lymphocyte predominance, but it's negative for bacterial, viral, and fungal growth. You've shown improvement and we can discharge you with a diagnosis of aseptic meningitis.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor.
Doctor: *Two months later* Welcome back. Are you experiencing similar symptoms as before?
Patient: Yes, unfortunately, the same symptoms have returned.
Doctor: Let's repeat the lumbar puncture and analyze your CSF again. The results show elevated white blood cells with lymphocyte predominance and elevated protein. We've also tested for various infections such as Cytomegalovirus, West Nile virus, herpes simplex virus, varicella zoster virus, and others, but all came back negative.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: We'll need to perform further assessment and screening for HIV 1/2, hepatitis A, B, C, infectious mononucleosis, Ehrlichia, Cryptococcus, and parvovirus infection.
Patient: Okay, please do whatever is necessary.
Doctor: All of those tests came back negative. We'll need to perform a bone marrow biopsy due to persistent pancytopenia.
Patient: I understand.
Doctor: The biopsy results are suspicious for a B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder. We've sent the specimen to Mayo Clinic for a second opinion. Their analysis found atypical lymphocytic infiltrate and irregular nuclear contours. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strongly positive CD20 expression, without co-expression of CD5 or CD10.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: The B-cell population has a lambda light chain restriction, and the atypical lymphocytes express BCL-2 protein and cyclin D1. The results of the bone marrow biopsy indicate a rare aberrant CD5 negative MCL.
Patient: Is it serious?
Doctor: The clinical picture and bone marrow investigations raise concerns about primary central nervous system (CNS) involvement. We'll need to continue monitoring and evaluating your condition to determine the best course of action.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports experiencing altered mental status for 3 days, accompanied by flu-like symptoms, severe headache, and pancytopenia. The symptoms have recurred after initial improvement following treatment for aseptic meningitis.
O: Physical examination revealed mild neck stiffness. Initial lab tests confirmed pancytopenia. CSF analysis showed elevated white blood cells with lymphocyte predominance, negative for bacterial, viral, and fungal growth. Repeat CSF analysis confirmed similar findings with elevated protein. Tests for various infections including CMV, WNV, HSV, VZV, HIV 1/2, hepatitis A, B, C, infectious mononucleosis, Ehrlichia, Cryptococcus, and parvovirus were negative. Bone marrow biopsy indicated a B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder with atypical lymphocytic infiltrate, irregular nuclear contours, and positive CD20 expression without co-expression of CD5 or CD10. Immunohistochemical analysis showed lambda light chain restriction, BCL-2 protein, and cyclin D1 expression, suggesting an aberrant CD5 negative MCL.
A: Primary diagnosis of aberrant CD5 negative mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) with suspected primary CNS involvement. Differential diagnosis initially included aseptic meningitis, but further testing led to the current diagnosis.
P: Continue monitoring and evaluation of the patient's CNS involvement. Plan for ongoing management includes further oncological assessment, potential chemotherapy or targeted therapy depending on staging and progression. Educate the patient on the nature of the diagnosis, treatment options, and potential outcomes. Arrange for regular follow-up visits to monitor the disease progression and response to treatment.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see from your history that you have hypertension, asthma, pulmonary fibrosis, and hyperthyroidism secondary to multinodular goiter. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having abdominal pain and diarrhea lately.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. We'll definitely look into it. You're currently admitted for possible colitis. Let's discuss your recent health situation. On admission, we found that you have acute kidney injury with serum creatinine of 2.8 mg/dL, while your baseline Scr was 1.2 mg/dL. Have you been taking any nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, proton pump inhibitors, or herbal medications recently?
Patient: No, I haven't been taking any of those. But I did take a course of clarithromycin for a respiratory infection about 2 weeks ago.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Are you currently taking any other medications?
Patient: Yes, I'm taking methimazole for my hyperthyroidism. I've been on it for about 2.5 years now.
Doctor: Okay, that's helpful to know. Do you smoke or use any illicit drugs? Can you tell me more about your social history?
Patient: No, I don't smoke or use any drugs, and there's nothing much to tell about my social history.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing all that. I must inform you that you have developed gross hematuria with worsening acute kidney injury. Our laboratory data shows elevated serum C-reactive protein, leukocytosis of 29.1 × 103/µL, blood urea nitrogen at 50 mg/dL, increased Scr to 5.67 mg/dL, and elevated potassium at 7.2 mg/dL.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We've done some further testing. You tested positive for antinuclear antibody (ANA, 1:640), perinuclear antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA, 1:320), and myeloperoxidase antibody (MPO, 109.4). However, you tested negative for human immunodeficiency virus, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, rheumatoid factor, ribonucleoprotein antibody, double stranded (ds)-DNA antibody, Sjogren SSA and SSB antibodies, and antiglomerular basement membrane (GBM) antibody.
Patient: What does all that mean?
Doctor: These results help us understand your condition better. Your serum complement levels are within normal limits, which is a good sign. Your C3 is 99 mg/dL, and C4 is 34 mg/dL, both within the reference range.
Patient: Okay, that's a relief.
Doctor: Additionally, your serum free light chain ratio is not elevated, and serum immunofixation did not show anything concerning.
Patient: So, what should I do now?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your condition and develop a treatment plan based on these findings. We may need to adjust your medications and conduct further tests as necessary. It's important to follow up with your healthcare team regularly.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I'll make sure to follow up as needed.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. We're here to help.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports recent abdominal pain and diarrhea. He has a history of hypertension, asthma, pulmonary fibrosis, and hyperthyroidism secondary to multinodular goiter. He denies the use of NSAIDs, PPIs, or herbal medications but took clarithromycin for a respiratory infection two weeks ago. He has been on methimazole for his hyperthyroidism for about 2.5 years. The patient does not smoke or use illicit drugs and has no significant social history to report.
O: On admission, the patient was noted to have acute kidney injury with a serum creatinine increase from a baseline of 1.2 mg/dL to 2.8 mg/dL, which has further worsened to 5.67 mg/dL. Current labs show leukocytosis (29.1 × 10^3/µL), elevated blood urea nitrogen (50 mg/dL), and hyperkalemia (potassium 7.2 mg/dL). The patient also developed gross hematuria. Serological tests were positive for ANA (1:640), p-ANCA (1:320), and MPO (109.4) but negative for HIV, hepatitis B and C, rheumatoid factor, ribonucleoprotein antibody, ds-DNA antibody, Sjogren SSA and SSB antibodies, and antiglomerular basement membrane antibody. Serum complement levels (C3 and C4) are within normal limits, and serum free light chain ratio and immunofixation are unremarkable.
A: The patient presents with worsening acute kidney injury, likely drug-induced nephrotoxicity from recent clarithromycin use, compounded by underlying chronic conditions. The presence of ANA, p-ANCA, and MPO antibodies suggests an autoimmune component, possibly vasculitis, contributing to renal and systemic symptoms. Differential diagnoses include drug-induced nephritis and autoimmune vasculitis.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of renal function and electrolytes, cessation of any potential nephrotoxic agents, and adjustment of current medications as necessary. A nephrology consult is recommended for further evaluation of suspected vasculitis and guidance on immunosuppressive therapy if confirmed. The patient should maintain hydration and avoid any new medications without prior consultation. Regular follow-up is essential to monitor his condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed. Further testing may include renal biopsy to clarify the etiology of kidney injury and guide treatment.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing sudden central abdominal pain for the past 7 hours. It's constant and doesn't go away. 
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any other symptoms, such as nausea or vomiting?
Patient: Yes, I've felt nauseous and have vomited a few times. My appetite has also reduced.
Doctor: Have you noticed any changes in your bowel habits or any urinary tract symptoms?
Patient: No, everything seems normal there. I even passed bowel motions without any difficulty earlier today.
Doctor: That's good to know. Can you tell me about your medical history? Have you had any previous medical problems or allergies?
Patient: I've been pretty healthy and have no known allergies.
Doctor: Do you smoke or consume alcohol?
Patient: I don't smoke, and I only drink alcohol occasionally.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Now, let's check your vital signs. On admission, your pulse is 63 beats per minute with a regular rhythm, temperature is 35.9°C, blood pressure is 132/73 mmHg, and your respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. During the examination, I noticed your abdomen is soft and non-distended with tenderness around your umbilical and suprapubic region. There's also fullness in your suprapubic region, which could be a distended bladder.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: We've also conducted some blood tests. Your liver and renal function seem normal, with an estimated glomerular filtration rate above 90, and your C-reactive protein is less than 3. However, you have a low haemoglobin level of 87.0 g dl–1, slightly low potassium at 3.3 mmol l–1, a raised white cell count of 12.4 × 10¹ l–1, a neutrophil count of 11.53 × 10¹ l–1, and a plasma lactate of 5 mmol l–1.
Patient: Oh, what does that mean?
Doctor: Your urine dipstick also showed ketones +3 and blood +4, but no leukocytes or nitrites. These results suggest that you might be experiencing an infection or inflammation in your body.
Patient: So, what's the treatment plan?
Doctor: We'll treat you conservatively with intravenous fluids and potassium replacement, antiemetics to help with nausea, and analgesia for the pain. After receiving fluids, we'll conduct a blood gas analysis to monitor your progress. The results show a pH of 7.3, lactate of 2.12, and base excess of 2.5, which indicates that you're responding well to the treatment.
Patient: That's good to hear. Is there anything else I need to do for my recovery?
Doctor: Just make sure to follow up with your primary care physician and monitor your symptoms closely. If you experience any worsening or new symptoms, please seek medical attention immediately.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports experiencing sudden, constant central abdominal pain for the past 7 hours, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The patient also notes a reduced appetite but normal bowel and urinary habits. The patient denies any significant past medical history or allergies and reports occasional alcohol consumption but no smoking.
O: Vital signs on admission include a pulse of 63 bpm, temperature of 35.9°C, blood pressure of 132/73 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 24 bpm. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness in the umbilical and suprapubic regions with suprapubic fullness. Laboratory findings show normal liver and renal function, low hemoglobin at 87.0 g/dl, slightly low potassium at 3.3 mmol/l, elevated white cell count at 12.4 × 10^9/l, neutrophil count at 11.53 × 10^9/l, and plasma lactate at 5 mmol/l. Urine dipstick shows ketones +3 and blood +4. Blood gas analysis post-treatment shows a pH of 7.3, lactate of 2.12, and base excess of 2.5.
A: The primary assessment is acute abdominal pain likely due to an underlying infection or inflammation, suggested by elevated white cell count, neutrophilia, and presence of ketones and blood in urine. Differential diagnoses could include urinary tract infection, gastrointestinal infection, or less likely, intra-abdominal abscess given the absence of leukocytosis and fever.
P: The management plan includes conservative treatment with intravenous fluids and potassium replacement, antiemetics for nausea, and analgesia for pain. The patient responded well to initial treatment as indicated by improved blood gas analysis. The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician, monitor symptoms closely, and seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or new symptoms appear.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you presented to the emergency department following an automotive accident where you were thrown from your motorcycle traveling approximately 35 mph. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what happened.
Doctor: Did you lose consciousness at any point during the accident?
Patient: No, I didn't.
Doctor: What symptoms are you experiencing right now?
Patient: I mainly have left wrist pain, and I noticed some tenderness and swelling.
Doctor: We have taken radiographs of your wrist to assess the situation. It appears that you have a volar dislocation and rotatory deformity of the proximal pole of the scaphoid. The distal pole remains properly located, articulating with the trapezium and trapezoid. No other injuries have been identified.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious.
Doctor: We attempted closed reduction in the emergency department, but it was not successful. Therefore, you elected to proceed with operative management. We used a dorsal approach to access the radiocarpal joint.
Patient: What did you find during the surgery?
Doctor: The scapholunate joint was completely disrupted, and the lunotriquetral joint was found to be unstable as well. The distal pole of the scaphoid appeared to be appropriately located without ligamentous disruption. No fractures or chondral injuries were seen.
Patient: How did you fix it?
Doctor: We placed three 0.045-inch K-wires into the proximal pole and used them as a joystick in concert with dorsally directed manual pressure over the distal pole to reduce the scaphoid dislocation. These wires were then advanced across the scapholunate articulation to hold the reduction. We also passed three more K-wires across the lunotriquetral joint to address the instability.
Patient: Did you find any more issues?
Doctor: We examined the distal pole again, but it did not demonstrate any instability. The capsule was closed with 0 VICRYL suture, and the K-wires were cut just below the skin. The subcutaneous layer was closed with buried 2–0 VICRYL suture, and the skin was closed with 4–0 NOVAFIL suture. Your wrist was then splinted.
Patient: How did I do after the surgery?
Doctor: You did well postoperatively, and we brought you back to the operating room eight weeks later for hardware removal. You went on to heal well and regained your wrist range of motion with occupational therapy.
Patient: That's great to hear! How am I doing now?
Doctor: At your most recent follow-up, five months since the injury, you have shown significant improvement. However, please continue with your occupational therapy and follow any further instructions provided by your therapist.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I will continue with my therapy and follow the instructions.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a motorcyclist, was involved in an accident at approximately 35 mph and was thrown from the motorcycle. He reports experiencing left wrist pain, tenderness, and swelling. He denies loss of consciousness during the accident.
O: Examination and radiographs of the left wrist revealed a volar dislocation and rotatory deformity of the proximal pole of the scaphoid, with the distal pole properly located. Closed reduction attempted in the emergency department was unsuccessful. Operative management included placement of three 0.045-inch K-wires and additional stabilization of the scapholunate and lunotriquetral joints. Postoperative recovery was noted to be good with successful hardware removal after eight weeks and significant improvement in wrist motion after occupational therapy.
A: The primary diagnosis is a volar dislocation of the scaphoid with associated instability of the scapholunate and lunotriquetral joints. No fractures or chondral injuries were identified. The prognosis is good given the patient's postoperative improvement and ongoing recovery with therapy.
P: The patient will continue with occupational therapy to further improve wrist function and should adhere to all therapeutic recommendations. Regular follow-up appointments will be necessary to monitor progress and ensure full recovery. Further interventions may be considered based on the patient's ongoing evaluation.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 33-year-old male with diabetes and a seizure disorder. What brings you to the emergency department today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing worsening dyspnea and hemoptysis lately.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Were you treated for any other conditions recently?
Patient: Yes, about two weeks ago, I was treated with antibiotics for community acquired pneumonia, but there wasn't much improvement.
Doctor: Oh, I see. Have you had any changes in your habits or exposures recently?
Patient: Well, I started vaping about 2 months ago, and I've been using it more and more, trying new flavors too.
