Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Have you used any recreational drugs in the past or currently?
Patient: No, I haven't used any recreational drugs.
Doctor: Alright. We performed a CT scan of your chest, which showed diffuse ground glass opacities and bilateral patchy consolidation. You also have worsening hypoxia, which required noninvasive ventilation. Your echocardiogram, however, is normal. We also conducted a bronchoscopic examination, but there were no airway lesions detected.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We further conducted a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL), which revealed increasing blood in four sequential aliquots, confirming the diagnosis of DAH. The BAL cell count showed more than 30,000 RBCs and 800 WBCs, with 42% neutrophils, 36% lymphocytes, 1% eosinophils, and 21% macrophages.
Patient: What about other tests?
Doctor: All inflammatory serologies were unremarkable, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP), rheumatoid factor (RF), antinuclear antibody (ANA), and anti-antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Your serum eosinophil count, anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) antibodies, and anti-phospholipid antibodies were all normal. A urine toxicology screen for amphetamines, cannabinoids, and cocaine was also negative. There was no microbiologic growth on all BAL specimens.
Patient: So, what's the treatment?
Doctor: You were treated with pulse dose steroids after DAH was confirmed with BAL aliquots. You also underwent a right wedge resection lung biopsy, which revealed evidence of bland pulmonary hemorrhage with no evidence of capillaritis or diffuse alveolar damage (DAD). Prussian blue iron staining was also noted, which reflects old hemorrhage.
Patient: Did my symptoms improve after the treatment?
Doctor: Yes, your symptoms improved with complete resolution of alveolar hemorrhage on a chest CT scan after 2 weeks. Your steroids were tapered quickly, and you haven't used a personal vaporizer since then.
Patient: That's a relief. I'll make sure not to use a vaporizer again. Thank you, doctor.
soap_note:
S: A 33-year-old male with a history of diabetes and seizure disorder presents with worsening dyspnea and hemoptysis. He reports no improvement after treatment with antibiotics for community-acquired pneumonia two weeks ago. The patient started vaping 2 months ago, increasing usage and trying new flavors, but denies any recreational drug use.
O: CT scan of the chest shows diffuse ground glass opacities and bilateral patchy consolidation. Noninvasive ventilation was required due to worsening hypoxia. Echocardiogram is normal. Bronchoscopic examination found no airway lesions. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) revealed increasing blood in four sequential aliquots, confirming diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). BAL cell count showed 30,000 RBCs, 800 WBCs, with 42% neutrophils, 36% lymphocytes, 1% eosinophils, and 21% macrophages. Inflammatory serologies including ESR, CRP, RF, ANA, and ANCA were unremarkable. Serum eosinophil count, anti-GBM antibodies, and anti-phospholipid antibodies were normal. Urine toxicology screen negative for amphetamines, cannabinoids, and cocaine. No microbiologic growth on BAL specimens. Right wedge resection lung biopsy indicated bland pulmonary hemorrhage without capillaritis or DAD. Prussian blue iron staining showed old hemorrhage.
A: Primary diagnosis is diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) likely related to vaping. Differential diagnoses such as infectious causes, autoimmune disorders, and drug-induced lung injury were considered but ruled out based on lab results and imaging.
P: Treatment initiated with pulse dose steroids following confirmation of DAH, with subsequent tapering as symptoms improved. The patient underwent a right wedge resection lung biopsy which supported the diagnosis. Advised complete cessation of vaping. Follow-up includes monitoring lung function and repeat imaging to ensure no recurrence. Education provided on the potential risks of vaping, especially with underlying health conditions.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you have been admitted due to a persistent temporal headache. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having this headache on the side of my head for a while now. It just doesn't seem to go away.
Doctor: I see. Besides the headache, have you experienced any other symptoms recently?
Patient: No, not really. Just the headache.
Doctor: Alright. We've taken your clinical history, performed a physical examination, and conducted some laboratory tests. Everything seems to be unremarkable so far. We also performed a nonenhanced computed tomography (CT) of your head, and it revealed a lesion with nonspecific attenuation in the left fossa of Rosenmüller. To further analyze this lesion, we conducted a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan.
Patient: Hmm, okay. What did the MRI show?
Doctor: The MRI showed that the lesion is pear-shaped and well-circumscribed. It appeared slightly hyperintense on T1-weighted images and hyperintense on fat-suppressed T2-weighted images. There was also subtle peripheral enhancement after the administration of gadolinium contrast.
Patient: So, what does that mean?
Doctor: Based on these findings, we have diagnosed you with a retention cyst in Rosenmüller's fossa. The good news is that you are asymptomatic, meaning you don't have any significant symptoms related to this cyst.
Patient: Oh, that's a relief. What should I do now?
Doctor: Since you're asymptomatic, we recommend watchful waiting. We'll keep an eye on the cyst, and you should inform us if you experience any new symptoms or if your headache worsens. Regular follow-ups will also be necessary.
Patient: Alright, I understand. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. Just make sure to keep in touch and update us on any changes in your condition. Take care.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports a persistent headache localized to the temporal region, described as ongoing and unilateral. No other symptoms were reported.
O: Physical examination and laboratory tests were unremarkable. Nonenhanced CT of the head revealed a lesion with nonspecific attenuation in the left fossa of Rosenmüller. Subsequent MRI findings indicated a pear-shaped, well-circumscribed lesion, slightly hyperintense on T1-weighted images and hyperintense on fat-suppressed T2-weighted images with subtle peripheral enhancement post-gadolinium contrast administration.
A: The primary diagnosis is a retention cyst in Rosenmüller's fossa. The patient is currently asymptomatic regarding the cyst, with the chief complaint being a headache that may or may not be related to the cyst.
P: The management plan includes watchful waiting, given the asymptomatic nature of the cyst. The patient is advised to monitor for any new symptoms or changes in the existing headache and to report these changes. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the cyst's status.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing some eye issues recently. I have a history of SS secondary to AIH and primary sclerosing cholangitis overlap.
Doctor: I see. Can you describe what kind of eye problems you've been having?
Patient: Yeah, my left eye has been really painful and I've noticed some keratolysis and even a corneal perforation.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Have you had any eye issues like this in the past?
Patient: Yes, I've had filiform keratitis and recurrent erosions for the previous 3 years. My eye disease worsened after I was in a coma in the intensive care unit due to a colon perforation and sepsis.
Doctor: That must have been a difficult time for you. When you were admitted to the emergency department, how was the condition of your right eye?
Patient: My right eye had deep corneal melting and my best corrected visual acuity was 0.2 decimal.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Over the past 10 months, you've had several surgical therapies performed on both your right and left eyes due to keratolysis and corneal perforations. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: After the surgeries, you were prescribed postoperative therapy, including dexamethasone disodium phosphate, cyclosporine, ofloxacin eye drops, artificial tears, and human albumin. Additionally, you were given mycophenolate mofetil systemically. How has that been working for you?
Patient: It's been helping somewhat, but I've continued to have issues with my eyes.
Doctor: I understand. Unfortunately, enhancement of your systemic immunosuppression with corticosteroids or azathioprine was contraindicated due to your history of sepsis. However, we did perform an off-label intravitreal injection of the FAc implant in your left eye 2 weeks after the second penetrating keratoplasty (PKP) because of new signs of corneal melting. How has your left eye been since then?
Patient: It's been better since the injection and the subsequent third PKP and amniotic membrane transplant.
Doctor: That's good to hear. In the 6 months of follow-up after the third PKP, your left eye has shown improvement, with a closed epithelium, BCVA of 0.16, and normal intraocular pressure without medication. However, during this time, you've also had two further PKPs, one vitrectomy, and five amniotic membrane transplants in your right eye. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Alright. Going forward, we will continue to monitor your progress and adjust your treatment as needed. Make sure to keep up with your postoperative therapy and attend any follow-up appointments.
Patient: Okay, thank you for your help, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any concerns or notice any changes in your eyes, don't hesitate to contact us. Take care.
soap_note:
S: Patient reports experiencing painful left eye with keratolysis and corneal perforation. History of filiform keratitis, recurrent erosions, and worsening eye disease post-coma due to colon perforation and sepsis. Right eye previously had deep corneal melting with best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of 0.2 decimal. Patient has undergone multiple surgical therapies including penetrating keratoplasty (PKP) and amniotic membrane transplants for both eyes. Current medications include dexamethasone disodium phosphate, cyclosporine, ofloxacin eye drops, artificial tears, human albumin, and mycophenolate mofetil systemically.
O: Left eye shows improvement post-intravitreal injection of FAc implant and third PKP with closed epithelium, BCVA of 0.16, and normal intraocular pressure without medication. Right eye has undergone two further PKPs, one vitrectomy, and five amniotic membrane transplants. Enhancement of systemic immunosuppression with corticosteroids or azathioprine is contraindicated due to history of sepsis.
A: Primary diagnosis is severe bilateral keratolysis with corneal perforations, secondary to systemic autoimmune conditions (SS secondary to AIH and primary sclerosing cholangitis overlap). Differential diagnosis includes ongoing severe autoimmune keratitis. Prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the eye conditions and systemic health issues.
P: Continue current postoperative therapy and systemic medications. Monitor eye condition closely with regular follow-up appointments. Adjust treatment plan as necessary based on progression or improvement of eye conditions. Educate patient on the importance of adhering to medication regimen and attending all follow-up appointments. Consider further surgical interventions if deterioration occurs.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see you're a 74-year-old man with an ASA physical class III. You're scheduled for a tumor-wide excision, mandibulotomy, tracheostomy, and free flap reconstruction because of mouth floor squamous cell carcinoma. Can you tell me about your medical history?
Patient: Yes, I have a history of hypertension and had a cystolitholapaxy for bilateral ureteral stones. I'm currently taking losartan and hydrochlorothiazide.
Doctor: Alright, and do you have any drug allergies?
Patient: No, I don't have any drug allergies.
Doctor: Good to know. Now, I see that you had a pre-operative chest radiograph taken 10 days before the surgery and it showed a normal picture. Your echocardiogram also indicated normal left ventricular function. Have you experienced any symptoms like a cough recently?
Patient: Yes, I've had a mild productive cough.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. We had a standard monitoring set-up for you, which includes an electrocardiogram, blood pressure, and SpO2. Your pre-operative vital signs were within normal range, with a heart rate of 74 bpm, blood pressure of 168/85 mmHg, respiration rate of 18 times per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: We induced general anesthesia with remifentanil (target-controlled infusion: 3 ng/mL), lidocaine (20 mg), propofol (180 mg), and succinylcholine (80 mg) following pre-oxygenation. Oral tracheal intubation was performed using a 7.5 mm endotracheal tube with a video-assisted intubating stylet. We did find some airway secretion during the tracheal intubation procedure, though.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: Mechanical ventilation was set at a volume-controlled mode, with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 10 times per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 4 cmH2O. We used sevoflurane at an end-expiration concentration of 2% and cis-atracurium for the maintenance of anesthesia. An arterial line was established through a radial artery for continuous beat-to-beat monitoring.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: During your surgery, we'll be closely monitoring your vital signs and adjusting the anesthesia as needed. After the surgery, you'll be carefully observed and given instructions for follow-up care. Do you have any questions or concerns?
Patient: No, I think you've explained everything well. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll do our best to ensure a successful surgery and recovery for you.
soap_note:
S: The patient is a 74-year-old male with a history of hypertension and bilateral ureteral stones, for which he underwent cystolitholapaxy. He is currently on losartan and hydrochlorothiazide. He reports a mild productive cough but no drug allergies. The patient is scheduled for tumor-wide excision, mandibulotomy, tracheostomy, and free flap reconstruction due to mouth floor squamous cell carcinoma.
O: Pre-operative chest radiograph and echocardiogram were normal. Pre-operative vital signs included a heart rate of 74 bpm, blood pressure of 168/85 mmHg, respiration rate of 18 times per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. General anesthesia was induced with remifentanil, lidocaine, propofol, and succinylcholine, and oral tracheal intubation was performed. Mechanical ventilation settings were volume-controlled with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 10 times per minute. An arterial line was established for continuous monitoring.
A: The primary diagnosis is mouth floor squamous cell carcinoma, with a history of hypertension and previous bilateral ureteral stones. The patient's vital signs and cardiac function are stable, suitable for the planned extensive surgical procedure. The mild productive cough will be monitored, though it does not currently suggest a complicating factor.
P: Proceed with the planned surgical procedure under general anesthesia and close monitoring of vital signs. Post-operative care will include pain management, infection prevention, and monitoring for any complications related to the surgery or anesthesia. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any long-term effects of the surgery. The patient will be educated on signs of complications to watch for and instructed on wound care and activity restrictions during recovery.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having this terrible pain in my sacral coccygeal area, and it's not going away.
Doctor: I see. Can you please tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: Sure, I have type 2 diabetes mellitus and I am taking linagliptin and metformin for it. I also have untreated high blood pressure, right-sided hemiparesis from meningitis in my childhood, nephrolithiasis, and a smoking history.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Let's perform a pelvic computed tomography (CT) to get a better understanding of your condition.
*After the CT scan*
Doctor: The CT scan shows a 9x7.5x9 cm bulky mass in your sacrum with locally increased soft tissue density, which is causing extensive lytic lesions of the sacred vertebrae and extending to the left iliac bone. This suggests a chordoma. We will need to perform a total sacrectomy with partial excision and reconstruction of the left iliac bone to remove the mass.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What about the examination of the mass?
Doctor: The anatomopathological examination revealed sacrococcygeal involvement by a thyroid carcinoma, as verified by immunohistochemical staining for thyroglobulin and TTF-1. It's predominantly the papillary (follicular variant), however, there are some foci of nondifferentiated (insular) carcinoma as well.
Patient: What about my thyroid?
Doctor: We performed a thyroid ultrasonography, which showed a solid nodule of 20 mm in the right lobe and two solid hypoechogenic nodules of 11 and 9 mm in the left lobe, with the smallest having coarse calcifications. No lymphadenopathies were found.
Patient: What's next, doctor?
Doctor: To get a better idea of the extent of the disease, we performed an 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose positron-emission tomography (18F-FDG-PET). It revealed a hypermetabolic focus in the left lobe of your thyroid, consistent with the suspected malignant neoplasia, and uptake of the radiopharmaceutical drug in the fifth lumbar vertebra and pelvic bones, indicating secondary involvement.
Patient: That's concerning. What do we do now?
Doctor: Consequently, we will perform a total thyroidectomy to remove the affected thyroid tissue.
*After the thyroidectomy*
Doctor: The histological examination of the removed thyroid tissue revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma with follicular and oxyphilic variants, but no insular carcinoma. The dimensions of the tumor foci range from 2 to 15 mm. There were no signs of hematogenic, lymphatic, or perineural permeation, invasion of the capsule, or extrathyroidal extension, and the resection margins were uninvolved by the tumor (pT1b[m]NxM1R0).
Patient: What's the next step in my treatment?
Doctor: You will undergo radioactive iodine therapy (RAI) to target any remaining cancer cells.
*After RAI treatment*
Doctor: The post-therapy scintigraphy shows hyperfixation of the radioactive iodine, which indicates that the treatment is working.
Patient: That's good news. Thank you, Doctor, for helping me through this.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll continue to monitor your progress and provide any necessary follow-up care.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports persistent pain in the sacral coccygeal area. The patient has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, treated with linagliptin and metformin, untreated high blood pressure, right-sided hemiparesis from childhood meningitis, nephrolithiasis, and a smoking history.
O: Pelvic CT scan revealed a 9x7.5x9 cm mass in the sacrum with increased soft tissue density, extensive lytic lesions of the sacral vertebrae, and extension to the left iliac bone, suggestive of a chordoma. Anatomopathological examination indicated sacrococcygeal involvement by thyroid carcinoma, predominantly papillary (follicular variant) with some foci of nondifferentiated (insular) carcinoma. Thyroid ultrasonography showed a 20 mm solid nodule in the right lobe and two solid hypoechogenic nodules in the left lobe, the smallest with coarse calcifications. 18F-FDG-PET scan showed hypermetabolic focus in the left thyroid lobe and uptake in the fifth lumbar vertebra and pelvic bones. Histological examination post-thyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma with follicular and oxyphilic variants, no insular carcinoma, and no signs of invasive features (pT1b[m]NxM1R0). Post-therapy scintigraphy after RAI treatment showed hyperfixation of radioactive iodine.
A: Primary diagnosis of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma with metastatic involvement of the sacrum and possibly other pelvic bones. Differential diagnosis initially included chordoma due to imaging findings, but histological results confirmed thyroid carcinoma metastasis.
P: The patient underwent total thyroidectomy followed by radioactive iodine therapy to eliminate residual cancer cells. The plan includes regular monitoring through follow-up visits and additional imaging studies as needed to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and detect any recurrence or progression of the disease. The patient's diabetes and blood pressure management will also be reviewed and adjusted as necessary to optimize overall health and treatment outcomes.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you've been admitted here at Chosun University Hospital in South Korea due to consistent low back pain. Can you tell me more about your symptoms and when they started?
Patient: Yes, doctor. I first started feeling chills and fever about a month ago. I went to a local hospital on November 24th, and they thought it might be acute pyelonephritis. They treated me with ceftriaxone at a dosage of 2 g daily.
Doctor: I see. Did your symptoms improve after that treatment?
Patient: Well, two days after admission, my back pain started. They continued the antibiotics for 18 days, and my blood cultures showed Salmonella enterica. The fever went away, and they couldn't detect any more bacteria in my follow-up cultures on the 8th and 25th days after starting treatment.
Doctor: So, you were discharged from the local hospital on December 19th, correct?
Patient: Yes, but I still suffered from lower back pain, nausea, and vomiting. I had to go back to the hospital just 9 days after discharge.
Doctor: When you were re-admitted to the local hospital on December 30th, did they perform any tests?
Patient: They did a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that showed L1 spondylitis. The MRI revealed whole bone marrow oedema with endplate lytic changes in the L1 body and focal marrow oedema in the upper endplate of L2 bodies. There was also mild destruction of the intervertebral disc at L1–2.
Doctor: Those findings indicate pyogenic spondylitis (Fig. a, b, c). How did they treat you for that?
Patient: They gave me cefazolin (1 g, 3 times a day) for 10 days to cover the possibility of a Staphylococcus aureus infection, which is a common cause of pyogenic spondylitis.
Doctor: Did they perform any more blood cultures during that time?
Patient: Yes, they did. The cultures yielded S. enterica again. That's when they decided to transfer me here to Chosun University Hospital.
Doctor: I understand. We performed a bone biopsy of your L spine on January 3rd, 2018. You currently have no fever, and the initial blood test results are in. We will analyze these results and create a treatment plan for you. We'll make sure to keep you and your family informed throughout the process.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help, and I hope we can finally get to the bottom of this.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports persistent lower back pain, initially presenting with chills and fever approximately one month ago. Initially suspected acute pyelonephritis and treated with ceftriaxone. Symptoms of fever resolved, but lower back pain persisted, leading to a diagnosis of L1 spondylitis on subsequent MRI. The patient also experienced nausea and vomiting.
O: Initial treatment with ceftriaxone 2 g daily for 18 days at a local hospital. Blood cultures positive for Salmonella enterica, later cleared. MRI showed L1 spondylitis with bone marrow edema and endplate lytic changes. Recent treatment included cefazolin 1 g three times daily for 10 days. Blood cultures reconfirmed S. enterica. Bone biopsy of the lumbar spine performed on January 3rd, 2018. Current vital signs stable with no fever.
A: Primary diagnosis of pyogenic spondylitis secondary to Salmonella enterica infection. Differential diagnosis includes other bacterial causes of spondylitis, such as Staphylococcus aureus, initially covered by cefazolin treatment.
P: Continue monitoring and supportive care for spondylitis, including pain management and possibly extending antibiotic therapy based on biopsy results and sensitivity patterns. Consult infectious disease for antibiotic management and rheumatology for spinal care. Educate patient and family about the nature of the infection and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan. Arrange follow-up appointments for re-evaluation and monitor for any signs of complications.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello there, I understand that you were diagnosed with pancreatic head cancer and underwent a pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) after receiving two courses of neoadjuvant chemotherapy with gemcitabine (GEM) and S-1 for 6 months preoperatively, based on the Japan Adjuvant Study Group of Pancreatic Cancer 04 study protocol.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Your ascites cytology came back negative for cancer cells, which is a good sign. Histopathologically, the tumor was diagnosed as a poorly differentiated, tubular adenocarcinoma. According to the UICC classification, seventh edition, the tumor was at stage pT2, N0, pStage IB, and we achieved R0.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: After the surgery, you received adjuvant S-1 therapy. Three months after PD, your blood tests showed coagulation derangements, and your C-reactive protein (CRP) was quite high at 11.30 mg/dl. A computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a 55-mm mass alongside your transverse colon. Did you feel any discomfort or pain at that time?
Patient: Yes, I remember feeling some discomfort and pain in my abdomen.
Doctor: During the 2-week follow-up, your coagulation derangement and elevated CRP (17.66 mg/dl) persisted. A repeat CT scan showed that the tumor had enlarged to 65 mm, and an additional mass, 25 mm in diameter, was detected in your jejunum. You were then hospitalized due to abdominal pain and diarrhea with persistent high fever. We inspected for infections, but there was no evidence of any.
Patient: Yes, it was a rough time.
Doctor: With the understanding that your life-threatening symptoms were secondary to the underlying malignancy, we performed extirpation of the tumors combined with partial resection of the transverse colon and the jejunum on the eighth day of hospitalization, on an emergency basis.
Patient: I remember that surgery.
Doctor: The histopathological findings of the two lesions showed that the tumor extended to the submucosal layer and occluded the lumen of the bowels. The lesions were identified as large and small bowel metastases from pancreatic cancer because the histopathological examination revealed morphological features similar to the primary disease. Your ascites cytology at this time was also negative for cancer.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Immediately after the emergency surgery, your fever resolved, and your CRP level normalized. How have you been feeling since then?
Patient: I've been feeling much better, thank you.
Doctor: That's great to hear. We will continue to monitor your condition closely and provide any necessary follow-up care. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any concerns or experience any symptoms.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: The patient, previously diagnosed with pancreatic head cancer, underwent a pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) after two courses of neoadjuvant chemotherapy with gemcitabine and S-1. Postoperatively, the patient experienced abdominal discomfort and pain, along with diarrhea and high fever. The patient reports feeling much better following the recent emergency surgery.
O: Initial histopathology confirmed a poorly differentiated, tubular adenocarcinoma, staged as pT2, N0, pStage IB, with R0 resection achieved. Post-PD, the patient developed coagulation derangements and elevated CRP levels (peak at 17.66 mg/dl). CT scans revealed a 55-mm mass near the transverse colon, later enlarging to 65 mm, and a new 25-mm mass in the jejunum. Emergency surgery was performed, removing both masses, identified as metastases from the primary pancreatic cancer. Post-surgery, the patient's fever resolved, and CRP levels normalized.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic pancreatic cancer, with complications including bowel obstruction and systemic inflammation indicated by elevated CRP and coagulation derangements. The patient's recent improvement post-emergency surgery suggests effective management of acute complications.
P: Continue close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups. Maintain adjuvant therapy with S-1 as tolerated, and manage any new symptoms aggressively. Educate the patient on signs of potential complications and ensure open lines for communication for any concerns or symptom developments.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you've been admitted to our hematology department with swelling, pain, skin redness, and increasing skin temperature in your right hip. Can you tell me if you have a history of any physical or psychological diseases, alcohol abuse, or similar issues in your family?
Patient: No, I don't have any history of physical or psychological diseases, and I don't abuse alcohol. I'm not aware of any family history of similar issues either.
Doctor: Okay, thank you. During your physical examination, we found a red mass in your right hip and a long strip of mass in your right groin area. There was no enlargement of your liver or spleen. We initially diagnosed you with a local infection and prescribed cephalosporin, but it seems like it didn't have any beneficial effects. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. The medication didn't really help with my symptoms.
Doctor: I see. We then conducted a subcutaneous puncture of your right buttock, and the results suggested hyperplastic lesions in the lymphoid tissue. We also found abnormal cells in your bone marrow, indicating significant lymphocyte infiltration (Fig. A). We performed a biopsy on the right groin area lymph node, and the pathology results showed abnormal hyperplastic lymphoid tissue invasion. The nucleus of these cells was irregularly shaped, the germinal center was atrophied, and the lymphoid structure was distinct from normal lymphoid tissue (Fig. B).
Patient: Oh, that sounds concerning.
Doctor: Yes, it is a cause for concern. The immunohistochemistry results of your right buttock tumor and right groin area lymph nodes were positive for CD5 (weak positive), CD20, CD21, CD23, and Bcl-2, but negative for CD3, CD10, and cyclin D1 (Table , Fig. ). These findings suggest that both the buttock tumor and the abnormal lymph nodes are non-Hodgkin marginal zone B cell lymphomas.
Patient: So, I have lymphoma?
Doctor: Yes, based on the results, it appears that you have non-Hodgkin marginal zone B cell lymphoma. We also performed positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) scans, which showed increased non-uniform fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) uptake in the subcutaneous tissue of your right buttock with an SUVmax of 11.6, an SUVmax of 9.1 in the right gluteal muscle space, and an SUVmax of 9.9 in multiple nodules on the right pelvic wall and right inguinal region (Fig. ). Considering the tumor aggressiveness on the same side of your diaphragm, the disease is considered to be in stage PE.
Patient: What does that mean for my treatment?
Doctor: We will discuss the best treatment options for you based on the stage and aggressiveness of the lymphoma. This may include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or a combination of both. We will also closely monitor your condition and make any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan.
Patient: I understand. Thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help you through this process.
soap_note:
S: The patient presents with swelling, pain, skin redness, and increased skin temperature in the right hip. The patient denies any personal or family history of physical or psychological diseases and alcohol abuse. Initial treatment with cephalosporin was ineffective.
O: Physical examination revealed a red mass in the right hip and a long strip of mass in the right groin area, with no hepatosplenomegaly noted. Subcutaneous puncture of the right buttock indicated hyperplastic lesions in lymphoid tissue. Bone marrow examination showed significant lymphocyte infiltration. Biopsy of the right groin lymph node showed abnormal hyperplastic lymphoid tissue with irregularly shaped nuclei and atrophied germinal centers. Immunohistochemistry was positive for CD5 (weak), CD20, CD21, CD23, and Bcl-2, and negative for CD3, CD10, and cyclin D1. PET/CT scans showed increased FDG uptake in the subcutaneous tissue of the right buttock (SUVmax 11.6), right gluteal muscle space (SUVmax 9.1), and multiple nodules on the right pelvic wall and right inguinal region (SUVmax 9.9).
A: The patient is diagnosed with non-Hodgkin marginal zone B cell lymphoma, localized to the right side of the diaphragm, indicating stage PE. The disease exhibits aggressive characteristics based on imaging and histopathological findings.
P: The treatment plan includes considering chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or a combination of both, tailored to the stage and aggressiveness of the lymphoma. Regular monitoring and adjustments to the treatment plan will be necessary. The patient will be educated about the disease process, treatment options, and potential side effects. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment response and manage any complications.

transcript:
Doctor: Hi, I understand that you are a 70-year-old bisexual man who was admitted with generalized myalgia and abdominal pain for the past 7 days. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I've been experiencing muscle aches all over my body and a constant pain in my abdomen.
Doctor: I see. I have your medical records here, and it says that you were diagnosed with an HIV infection during an evaluation of a fever three months ago. At that time, your HIV RNA level was 36,500 copies/mL, with 114 CD4+ lymphocytes/μL, meeting the definition of AIDS, although the exact timing of the HIV infection was unknown. 
Patient: Oh, yes. I remember that.
Doctor: Your records also show that you had a chest and abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan, which showed no abnormalities, and an ophthalmologic examination showed no evidence of ocular disease. Additionally, you tested positive for anti-cytomegalovirus (CMV) IgG. Since then, you have been treated with an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI)-based regimen, including elvitegravir, cobicistat, tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, and emtricitabine, and have shown good adherence to the medications. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. I've been taking my medications as prescribed.
Doctor: Good. Now, regarding your current admission, your vital signs were as follows: blood pressure, 110/80 mmHg; pulse rate, 98/min; body temperature, 38.0 °C; and respiratory rate, 20/min. During the physical examination, there was no localized tenderness in your abdomen. However, the laboratory findings showed anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.7 g/dL, thrombocytopenia with platelets at 53 × 103/mm3, acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL, and an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level (LDH) of 6608 U/L. Your HIV-RNA was undetectable at less than 20 copies/mL, and you had 256 CD4+ lymphocytes/μL.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We also conducted an abdominal CT, which revealed multiple liver masses, as shown in Fig. To differentiate between liver abscess and malignancy, a core needle biopsy was performed. The biopsy showed an atypical lymphocytic population composed of medium-sized basophilic cells on hematoxylin and eosin staining.
Patient: What does that mean, exactly?
Doctor: Immunohistochemistry tests were positive for B cell markers CD20 and CD79a, and the Ki-67 labelling index approached 90%. This indicates that the tumor is likely a type of lymphoma, a cancer that starts in the immune system cells.
Patient: Oh no, that's terrible.
Doctor: I understand this is difficult news, but it's important that we caught this early. We will work together to develop a treatment plan and monitor your progress closely. It's crucial to maintain open communication and follow the prescribed treatments.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and guidance during this time.
soap_note:
S: The patient is a 70-year-old bisexual man presenting with generalized myalgia and constant abdominal pain persisting for 7 days. He has a history of HIV diagnosed three months ago, with initial labs showing an HIV RNA level of 36,500 copies/mL and CD4 count of 114 cells/μL. He reports good adherence to his INSTI-based antiretroviral therapy.
O: Current vital signs are blood pressure 110/80 mmHg, pulse 98/min, temperature 38.0 °C, and respiratory rate 20/min. Physical examination shows no localized abdominal tenderness. Lab findings indicate anemia (hemoglobin 9.7 g/dL), thrombocytopenia (platelets 53 × 10^3/mm^3), acute kidney injury (creatinine 1.8 mg/dL), and elevated LDH (6608 U/L). HIV RNA is undetectable (<20 copies/mL), and CD4 count has improved to 256 cells/μL. Abdominal CT revealed multiple liver masses. Biopsy of the liver masses showed atypical lymphocytic population, with immunohistochemistry positive for CD20 and CD79a, and a high Ki-67 index of 90%, suggestive of lymphoma.
A: The primary diagnosis is lymphoma, likely secondary to chronic immunosuppression from HIV/AIDS. Differential diagnoses could include other malignancies or infectious processes, but these are less likely given the biopsy results. The patient's HIV is currently well-controlled with undetectable viral load and improving CD4 count.
P: The management plan will include referral to oncology for further evaluation and treatment of lymphoma. Continue current antiretroviral regimen with close monitoring of adherence and potential drug interactions. Address supportive care needs, including management of anemia and thrombocytopenia, and monitor renal function. Educate the patient on the importance of maintaining treatment adherence and regular follow-up appointments to monitor his condition and treatment response.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having this right ankle pain for 4 years now. It started when I lost a significant amount of weight and began physical activity.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any history of trauma to the ankle?
Patient: No, there's no history of trauma.
Doctor: Alright. What initial diagnosis did you receive and what treatments have you tried?
Patient: I was first diagnosed with synovitis and underwent physical therapy, but it didn't help much.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Can you describe your symptoms in more detail?
Patient: Sure. I have paraesthesia along the posterior and medial aspect of my ankle and foot. The pain gets worse at the end of the day, and I also experience cramping episodes in my foot.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Let's perform a physical examination. *Doctor performs the examination* Your dorsiflexion-eversion test is positive, provoking numbness of the foot. Also, your Tinel's sign is positive. Your ankle range of motion seems to be limited due to pain, and I would score it an 8 on the Visual Analog Score (VAS). 
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: Yes, it does indicate some issues. Based on your preoperative score of 40 points according to the American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS), we performed bilateral electromyography (EMG), which revealed abnormal adductor hallucis and adductor digiti quinti neurophysiologic parameters compared to the asymptomatic side.
Patient: What did the tests show?
Doctor: Initial plain radiographs showed a considerable 1.8 cm posterior bone fragment in relation with the talus. A CT scan was then performed, which showed the presence of an articulated accessory bone. At this point, we suspected a talus bipartitus (TB) diagnosis.
Patient: Hmm, and what about the MRI?
Doctor: The MRI disclosed the presence of an inflammatory process, a bone fragment covered with cartilage, and what appears to be a degenerative synchondrosis as a consequence of posteromedial impingement.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: In this scenario, a surgical procedure is indicated due to increasing symptoms and several conservative treatment trials with no response. We need to conduct a preoperative assessment, including three-dimensional CT scan images, to get full awareness of the bone fragment's specific anatomy.
Patient: Is there anything else you need to assess?
Doctor: Yes, we will also assess the anatomic relationship between the tibial nerve, posterior tibial artery, flexor hallucis longus, flexor digitorium longus, and tibialis posterior tendon and the bone fragment with the help of MRI. Although fixation of the accessory bone has been previously done, it's essential to understand the exact situation in your case.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything. I'm ready to proceed with the necessary steps.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll do our best to provide you with the best possible treatment and care.
soap_note:
S: Patient reports chronic right ankle pain persisting for 4 years, exacerbated by weight loss and initiation of physical activity. No history of trauma. Initial diagnosis was synovitis; however, physical therapy was ineffective. Symptoms include paraesthesia along the posterior and medial aspect of the ankle and foot, worsening pain by day's end, and cramping episodes. No relief from previous conservative treatments.
O: Physical examination revealed positive dorsiflexion-eversion test and Tinel's sign, limited ankle range of motion with a pain score of 8 on the Visual Analog Score (VAS). American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) preoperative score was 40. Bilateral electromyography (EMG) showed abnormal neurophysiologic parameters in adductor hallucis and adductor digiti quinti. Radiographs and CT scan identified a 1.8 cm posterior bone fragment related to the talus and an articulated accessory bone. MRI indicated an inflammatory process, a cartilage-covered bone fragment, and degenerative synchondrosis due to posteromedial impingement.
A: Primary diagnosis of talus bipartitus (TB) with associated posteromedial impingement and degenerative synchondrosis. Differential diagnosis initially included synovitis, ruled out by further imaging and symptomatology.
P: Plan to proceed with surgical intervention due to lack of response to conservative treatments and progressive symptoms. Preoperative assessment will include three-dimensional CT scans to detail the bone fragment's anatomy and MRI to assess the anatomical relationship of nearby structures. Patient education on surgical risks, benefits, and recovery process. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled post-surgery to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. Can you tell me what happened before you lost consciousness?
Patient: Yeah, I suddenly felt really dizzy and then just blacked out.
Doctor: You were admitted to the emergency hospital in a comatose state. We diagnosed you with a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) due to a rupture of the right vertebral artery dissecting aneurysm. To treat this, we performed an artery occlusion and ventricular drainage due to hydrocephalus. Nutrition was provided through a nasogastric tube. How are you feeling now?
Patient: Hmm, I'm feeling much better now, thank you.
Doctor: That's good to hear. After you gradually recovered consciousness, you required ventilation for a month. Once weaned from the ventilator, we installed a speech cannula at the tracheotomy site. Unfortunately, you developed pneumonia during that time, but we treated it with antibiotics. Now, you've been transferred here for rehabilitation.
Patient: Yeah, I remember that. It was a tough time.
Doctor: I understand. I see you have a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, but no history of respiratory diseases or sleep disturbance. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct. I don't smoke either.
Doctor: Good to know. Your Epworth sleepiness scale score was 7 before the SAH. Now, let's go over your physical examination. You're 180 centimeters tall and weigh 82.6 kg. Your blood pressure is 126/81 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, and respiratory rate is 19 breaths/min. Your O2 saturation is 88% on room air and improves to 97% on 1 L of oxygen per minute. 
Patient: Okay, I see.
Doctor: Your cardiovascular examination is normal, and your lungs are clear on auscultation. Your abdominal examination is also unremarkable. On neurological examination, you're alert with a MMSE score of 28. Eye movements are normal, but there's mild narrowing of your right palpebral fissure and a constricted pupil with preserved light reflex in your right eye. 
Patient: Oh, I didn't notice that.
Doctor: Additionally, you have mild arm and hand paresis and moderate leg paresis on the right side. Your deep tendon reflexes are brisk on the right side, and the Babinski reflex on the right side is extensor. Your right arm is ataxic, and the presence of ataxia is unequivocal in your right leg due to moderate paresis. Lastly, superficial sensation on the left side, including the face, is decreased. 
Patient: That explains the difficulties I've been having with my limbs.
Doctor: Yes, it's important to be aware of these issues as you continue your rehabilitation. We'll work on improving your strength and sensation during your therapy sessions. It's crucial to follow your rehabilitation plan and attend all scheduled appointments to maximize your recovery.
Patient: I understand, I'll do my best. Thank you, doctor.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a non-smoker with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, reported sudden dizziness followed by loss of consciousness. He has no history of respiratory diseases or sleep disturbances. He felt much better after the initial treatment but recalled the difficulty during the recovery phase, including a month of ventilation and a subsequent pneumonia treated with antibiotics.
O: The patient was initially diagnosed with a subarachnoid hemorrhage due to a ruptured right vertebral artery dissecting aneurysm. Treatment included artery occlusion, ventricular drainage for hydrocephalus, and nutrition via a nasogastric tube. Current vital signs show a blood pressure of 126/81 mm Hg, pulse 76/min, respiratory rate 19 breaths/min, and O2 saturation 88% on room air, improving to 97% on 1 L of oxygen per minute. Neurological examination reveals alertness with a MMSE score of 28, mild right arm and hand paresis, moderate right leg paresis, brisk deep tendon reflexes on the right, extensor Babinski reflex on the right, ataxia in the right arm and leg, and decreased superficial sensation on the left side.
A: The primary diagnosis is subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to a ruptured right vertebral artery dissecting aneurysm, complicated by hydrocephalus, pneumonia, and residual neurological deficits including hemiparesis and sensory loss. The patient's recovery is ongoing, with significant improvements but persistent neurological challenges.
P: Continue rehabilitation focusing on strength and sensory improvement. Monitor neurological status and adjust therapies as needed. Ensure adherence to the rehabilitation schedule to maximize recovery. Regular follow-ups with neurology and physical therapy are recommended. Educate the patient on the importance of compliance with the rehabilitation plan to improve functional outcomes.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I had a tonic-clonic seizure a week ago and I wanted to get it checked out.
Doctor: I see. Let's start by ordering a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan to take a closer look at your brain. 
*After the MRI scan*
Doctor: The MRI scan showed a 10 cm left frontal tumor. We need to perform a craniotomy and resection to remove the tumor and confirm its nature.
Patient: Okay, that sounds serious. Please go ahead with the surgery.
*After the surgery*
Doctor: The tumor has been removed and it was confirmed as an atypical meningioma. You will need to take 400 mg of phenytoin PO once a day to prevent any seizures postoperatively.
Patient: Alright, I'll do that.
Doctor: Good news is that you had no seizures after the surgery. Additionally, you received 60 Gy of adjuvant radiation therapy to the postoperative bed in 30 fractions.
Patient: Yes, everything seemed fine until three months after the resection. I developed symptoms consistent with a generalized seizure.
Doctor: I understand. Let's resume your daily phenytoin prophylaxis with good effect.
*Two months later*
Patient: I've been noticing blood in my stool lately.
Doctor: We should run an evaluation to get a proper diagnosis.
*After the evaluation*
Doctor: You have been diagnosed with a locally advanced nonmetastatic adenocarcinoma of the low rectum. We will prescribe a curative-intent dose of 50.4 Gy in 28 fractions of neoadjuvant radiation therapy along with 2000 mg PO BID of concurrent radiosensitizing capecitabine.
Patient: Okay, I'll follow the treatment plan.
*After 20 of the planned 28 fractions*
Patient: I started feeling unwell, and I'm experiencing new, right-sided upper and lower limb dysfunction and an unsteady gait.
Doctor: Let's order a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of your brain to check for any suspicious findings.
*After the CT scan*
Doctor: The CT scan showed no suspicious findings. However, your phenytoin level was dramatically elevated at 138 µmol/L, compared to 49 µmol/L just prior to neoadjuvant therapy. The normal range is 40-80 µmol/L. Your albumin level is also normal at 39 g/L and you're taking no other medications other than an occasional stimulant laxative.
Patient: What should we do now?
Doctor: We will discontinue the capecitabine and treat you with charcoal. You will be admitted for observation. We will temporarily discontinue phenytoin and then reintroduce it at the previous dose of 400 mg PO per day once levels begin to normalize.
Patient: Alright, I hope that helps.
Doctor: Your symptoms quickly resolved, and you showed no further complications. Keep following your treatment plan and let me know if you experience any issues in the future.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: The patient reported a tonic-clonic seizure a week ago, which led to the discovery of a left frontal tumor via MRI. Post-surgical pathology confirmed it as an atypical meningioma. The patient was placed on 400 mg of phenytoin daily postoperatively and received 60 Gy of adjuvant radiation therapy. Three months post-resection, the patient experienced a generalized seizure and resumed phenytoin. Recently, the patient reported blood in the stool and was diagnosed with locally advanced nonmetastatic adenocarcinoma of the low rectum. The patient began neoadjuvant radiation therapy and concurrent radiosensitizing capecitabine but developed right-sided limb dysfunction and an unsteady gait.
O: MRI revealed a 10 cm left frontal tumor. Postoperative diagnosis confirmed atypical meningioma. The patient received 60 Gy of radiation in 30 fractions. Recent symptoms led to a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the low rectum, treated with 50.4 Gy in 28 fractions and 2000 mg PO BID capecitabine. A CT scan showed no new brain abnormalities. Phenytoin level was elevated at 138 µmol/L (normal range 40-80 µmol/L). Albumin level was normal at 39 g/L.
A: Primary diagnoses are atypical meningioma status post resection and radiation, and locally advanced nonmetastatic adenocarcinoma of the low rectum currently undergoing treatment. Complications include elevated phenytoin levels likely due to interaction with capecitabine, leading to right-sided limb dysfunction and unsteady gait.
P: Discontinue capecitabine and treat with charcoal. Admit for observation and temporarily discontinue phenytoin, reintroducing at 400 mg PO daily once levels normalize. Continue monitoring phenytoin levels and adjust dosage as necessary. Complete the remaining radiation therapy fractions for rectal cancer as tolerated. Follow up regularly to monitor for any further complications or recurrence of symptoms.

transcript:
Doctor: Hi, I see you've presented today with an 8-week history of persistent low back and left buttock pain, as well as difficulty walking and sitting. Can you tell me more about when these symptoms started?
Patient: Yes, the symptoms started at 34 weeks of pregnancy. I had similar complaints during my previous pregnancy, and they were attributed to sciatica.
Doctor: I see. And both your pregnancies were delivered with cesarean section, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Have you experienced any recent trauma or been involved in any strenuous physical activity that could be related to your symptoms?
Patient: No, I haven't had any trauma or been involved in any strenuous activities.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. On examination, you were apyretic, 164 cm tall, and weighed 48 kg. We noticed pain and mild tenderness on palpation of your left superior gluteal area. Pain was aggravated during provocative sacroiliac joint maneuvers. Your lumbar spine was slightly painful at extension and lateral bending. Neurologic examination was normal. We also conducted some laboratory investigations, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate, blood calcium, phosphorus levels, and kidney and thyroid tests, all of which were normal.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: We also performed pelvic and lumbar x-rays, which revealed no bone abnormalities. However, a pelvic CT scan showed degenerative changes concordant with a left mechanical sacroiliac joint (SIJ) disease, as seen in Fig. A. A subsequent MRI revealed a hypointense oblique line with marrow edema on the left side of the sacrum, consistent with a stress fracture, as shown in Fig. B.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: For treatment, we recommend relative rest and pain killers. This approach has resulted in favorable outcomes for similar cases.
Patient: Alright, I'll follow your instructions.
Doctor: Great. Just to let you know, our case was waived from ethical approval according to our institutional ethical committee, and we have obtained informed consent from you for the procedures performed.
Patient: Yes, I understand.
Doctor: If you have any further concerns or questions, please don't hesitate to reach out. We'll monitor your progress and adjust the treatment plan as needed.
Patient: Thank you for your help, doctor.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a postpartum female, reports an 8-week history of persistent low back and left buttock pain, which began at 34 weeks of pregnancy. She describes difficulty walking and sitting, similar to symptoms experienced during a previous pregnancy, which were diagnosed as sciatica. Both pregnancies were delivered via cesarean section. The patient denies any recent trauma or involvement in strenuous activities.
O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be apyretic with a height of 164 cm and weight of 48 kg. There was pain and mild tenderness upon palpation of the left superior gluteal area, with pain exacerbation during provocative sacroiliac joint maneuvers. Lumbar spine examination showed slight pain on extension and lateral bending. Neurological examination was normal. Laboratory tests including erythrocyte sedimentation rate, blood calcium, phosphorus levels, and kidney and thyroid function tests were within normal limits. Pelvic and lumbar x-rays showed no bone abnormalities. Pelvic CT and MRI indicated degenerative changes and a stress fracture in the left sacroiliac joint and sacrum, respectively.
A: The primary diagnosis is left mechanical sacroiliac joint disease with an associated stress fracture of the sacrum. The differential diagnosis previously considered was sciatica, particularly given the patient's history during pregnancy. The prognosis is generally favorable with appropriate management.
P: The management plan includes relative rest and pain management with analgesics. The patient has been advised to follow up for monitoring of her condition and adjustment of the treatment plan as necessary. She has been informed about the procedures and has given informed consent. Further consultations with a physiotherapist may be considered to aid in recovery and prevent future complications. The patient is encouraged to contact the healthcare provider if symptoms persist or worsen.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I heard you were admitted due to repeated loss of consciousness, concomitant with a pale face, palpitations, and convulsions. Can you tell me more about these symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I've been experiencing these symptoms for 2 years, but they've been aggravated during the past 2 months. They occur automatically and I don't experience any sweating, nausea, vomiting, trembling, or an obvious sense of hunger before meals.
Doctor: I see. I understand you were previously misdiagnosed with epilepsy in another hospital, but we found no abnormal findings on your 24-hour electroencephalogram. We conducted some imaging tests, such as abdominal perfusion CT and magnetic resonance scan. The scans confirmed a highly perfused nodule within the pancreatic tail, measuring 11.6 x 13.2 mm (Fig. -).
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Additionally, we performed a 68Ga-exendin 4 PET-CT which showed a region in the pancreatic tail with abnormally high metabolism and overexpression of the glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor (Fig. -). Lab testing showed a low fasting blood glucose of 2.2 mmol/L (reference range: 3.9–6.1 mmol/L), a high proinsulin level of 4455.9 pg/mL (reference range: 30–180 ng/mL), a normal C-peptide level of 2.56 ng/mL (reference range: 0.8–4.2 ng/mL), a serum insulin level of 15.35 μIU/mL (reference range: 5.2–17.2 μIU/mL), and a gastrin level of 92.6 pg/mL (reference range: < 100 pg/mL).
Patient: Hmm, so what does that mean?
Doctor: Based on these results, we have confirmed a diagnosis of insulinoma. We also performed imaging examinations to check for any abnormalities indicative of parathyroid adenoma or malignancy in the pituitary or adrenal glands, and found no abnormalities.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: Furthermore, lab testing showed normal levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH), blood calcium, phosphate, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), growth hormone (GH), prolactin (PRL), adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), and 24-hour urinary free cortisol.
Patient: Okay, so what's the next step?
Doctor: Now that we have a confirmed diagnosis, we will discuss treatment options for your insulinoma. It's important that you continue to monitor your symptoms and follow up with us regularly.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me. I'll make sure to follow up with you.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports repeated episodes of loss of consciousness, pale face, palpitations, and convulsions over the past 2 years, with an increase in frequency and severity in the last 2 months. The patient denies associated symptoms such as sweating, nausea, vomiting, trembling, or hunger before meals. Previously misdiagnosed with epilepsy.
O: Vital signs unreported. Abdominal imaging revealed a highly perfused 11.6 x 13.2 mm nodule in the pancreatic tail. 68Ga-exendin 4 PET-CT indicated high metabolism and overexpression of glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor in the same region. Lab results showed low fasting blood glucose at 2.2 mmol/L, elevated proinsulin at 4455.9 pg/mL, normal C-peptide at 2.56 ng/mL, normal serum insulin at 15.35 μIU/mL, and normal gastrin at 92.6 pg/mL. Additional tests for parathyroid adenoma, pituitary, and adrenal malignancies were negative with normal levels of PTH, calcium, phosphate, FSH, GH, PRL, ACTH, and 24-hour urinary free cortisol.
A: Primary diagnosis of insulinoma confirmed by imaging and lab findings. Differential diagnoses such as parathyroid adenoma, pituitary, and adrenal malignancies were considered but ruled out based on normal imaging and hormonal assays.
P: Plan to discuss treatment options for insulinoma, emphasizing the importance of regular monitoring and follow-up. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease and potential treatment modalities will be provided. Regular follow-ups to monitor treatment response and adjust as necessary.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented to our vascular clinic today. Can you tell me if you have any symptoms or concerns?
Patient: Hi, doctor. No, I don't have any specific symptoms, but I recently had a computed tomography (CT) scan and they found something.
Doctor: Yes, I have your report here. You have an asymptomatic 10 cm AAA, which was identified as an incidental finding on your CT scan. Do you have any history of hypertension or other medical issues?
Patient: I do have mild hypertension, and I'm taking medication for it.
Doctor: Okay, during the physical examination, we noticed a large pulsating mass in your abdomen, but your femoral and tibial vessels have normal pulsation. Have you experienced any intermittent claudication or pain in your legs while walking?
Patient: No, I haven't had any complaints like that.
Doctor: We have planned an open repair for your aneurysm. How are you feeling about this surgical procedure?
Patient: I'm very anxious about the results and possible complications. I have a lot of stress and phobia about surgery.
Doctor: I understand your concerns. We've consulted a psychiatrist to help you with your anxiety. To better define the aneurysm anatomy, we performed a new CT angiography (CTA) 48 hours after your admission.
Patient: What did the new scan show?
Doctor: The CTA revealed complete thrombosis of the AAA, just below both renal arteries, without any signs of acute renal insufficiency, mesenteric ischemia, or limb ischemia. The most impressive element was the rich collateralization between the thoracic aorta and the common femoral arteries which wasn't evident in your first CT scan.
Patient: Oh, that's interesting. What does it mean for me?
Doctor: During the following physical examination, we found the absence of the previous pulsating mass and absence of femoral and distal leg pulses. Your legs are warm with normal skin color. We've decided to postpone the surgical procedure and discharge you with double antiplatelet therapy and weekly follow-up for possible signs of limb ischemia.
Patient: I see. What happened after that?
Doctor: After a month, you presented with severe intermittent claudication in your left lower limb. We performed a digital subtraction angiogram which revealed a thrombosed abdominal aorta with collateral vessels between the aorta and both common femoral arteries.
Patient: So, what was the next step?
Doctor: You underwent a left axillary-femoral bypass with a polytetrafluoroethylene No. 8 graft. Your postoperative course was uneventful, and the symptom of intermittent claudication disappeared.
Patient: That's a relief. What's the plan for my discharge?
Doctor: We will discharge you on the fourth postoperative day with antiplatelet therapy (salicylic acid 100 mg, once daily) and a statin. Please continue taking these medications and follow up with us as needed.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap_note:
S: The patient, who has a history of mild hypertension managed with medication, presented to the vascular clinic without specific symptoms. An incidental finding of a 10 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was noted on a CT scan. The patient reported significant anxiety about the upcoming surgical procedure and denied any symptoms of intermittent claudication or leg pain.
O: Initial physical examination revealed a large pulsating mass in the abdomen with normal femoral and tibial pulses. A subsequent CT angiography showed complete thrombosis of the AAA just below the renal arteries, with extensive collateralization and no signs of acute complications. Physical examination post-CTA noted the absence of the previously detected pulsating mass and femoral pulses, though leg warmth and skin color were normal. A digital subtraction angiogram performed later confirmed a thrombosed abdominal aorta with collateral vessels. The patient underwent a successful left axillary-femoral bypass using a polytetrafluoroethylene No. 8 graft.
A: The primary diagnosis is a thrombosed AAA with collateral vessel formation, complicated by severe intermittent claudication in the left lower limb, which was surgically managed with a bypass graft. The patient's anxiety regarding surgery was addressed with psychiatric consultation.
P: The patient will be discharged on the fourth postoperative day with a prescription for antiplatelet therapy (salicylic acid 100 mg daily) and a statin. Continued medication adherence and regular follow-up visits are advised to monitor the patient's vascular status and manage any potential complications. The patient is also encouraged to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you're a long-distance truck driver and you've come in today with severe retrosternal chest pain, diaphoresis, and vomiting for the past two days. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. The pain has been constant and really bad.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any loss of consciousness during this time?
Patient: Actually, yes. I lost control of my truck for a few seconds after an episode of severe chest pain, but luckily no one was injured.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear no one was hurt. Do you have a history of hypertension or elevated cholesterol levels?
Patient: Yes, I have both.
Doctor: Alright, and do you have any history of heart disease, cough, or pleuritic pain? Also, do you smoke or drink alcohol?
Patient: No, I don't have any history of heart disease, cough, or pleuritic pain, and I don't smoke or drink.
Doctor: Thank you for that information. During your physical examination, we found that you have hypertension with a blood pressure of 160/100 mm Hg and a low-grade fever with an axillary temperature of 37.5°C. We admitted you to the hospital to investigate the possibility of an acute coronary syndrome. However, your echocardiogram findings and serum troponin levels were normal. On the second day of your admission, you experienced bloody vomiting. Do you also have pain when swallowing?
Patient: Yes, I do.
Doctor: We learned that you were taking ceftriaxone injections and Doxycycline 100 mg capsules twice per day for four days, prescribed by another health facility for a febrile illness. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Okay. Since you don't have any prior history of esophageal disease, we consulted a gastroenterologist and performed an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) on you. We found multiple mucosal ulcerations in your proximal and middle esophagus, as well as at the lower esophageal sphincter. Additionally, there were hyperemia and erosions in both your stomach and duodenum. Mild bleeding was also noted.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Your laboratory tests were normal except for a mild transient elevation of liver transaminases and a triglyceride level of 243 mg per deciliter. Your serum albumin and bilirubin were normal, and you tested negative for Hepatitis B surface antigen. We will continue to monitor your condition and discuss the best course of treatment to address these issues.
Patient: Alright, thank you, Doctor.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a long-distance truck driver, presents with severe retrosternal chest pain, diaphoresis, and vomiting for the past two days. He reports the pain as constant and severe, with an episode of loss of consciousness while driving. The patient has a history of hypertension and elevated cholesterol levels but denies any history of heart disease, cough, pleuritic pain, smoking, or alcohol consumption. He also experiences pain when swallowing.
O: Physical examination revealed hypertension (160/100 mm Hg) and a low-grade fever (37.5°C). An echocardiogram and serum troponin levels were normal. The patient was found to have bloody vomiting on the second day of admission. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) showed multiple mucosal ulcerations in the proximal and middle esophagus and at the lower esophageal sphincter, with hyperemia and erosions in the stomach and duodenum. Laboratory tests indicated mild transient elevation of liver transaminases and a triglyceride level of 243 mg/dL. Serum albumin and bilirubin were normal, and Hepatitis B surface antigen was negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is esophageal ulceration likely caused by doxycycline-induced injury, considering the temporal relationship between the drug intake and symptom onset. Differential diagnoses initially included acute coronary syndrome, but cardiac investigations were normal. The presence of hypertension and elevated triglycerides also suggests an ongoing risk for cardiovascular complications.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of doxycycline and initiation of a proton pump inhibitor to manage esophageal ulceration. The patient will be monitored for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and liver function. Dietary modifications will be advised to avoid further esophageal irritation. A follow-up with a gastroenterologist is scheduled, and cardiovascular risk factors will be managed by adjusting antihypertensive therapy and initiating lipid-lowering treatment. Patient education will focus on the importance of medication compliance and potential side effects of prescribed drugs.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented to our emergency department of the level I county trauma center. What brings you here today?
Patient: Hi, I've had jaw pain for the past three days and it's really bothering me.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Have you experienced any other symptoms recently?
Patient: Yeah, I've also had some abdominal bloating.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Can you tell me about your medical history? Do you have any chronic conditions or take any medications?
Patient: I have hypertension, but I don't take any medications for it.
Doctor: Alright. Do you have any allergies or use tobacco, alcohol, or drugs?
Patient: No, I don't have any allergies, and I don't use tobacco, alcohol, or drugs.
Doctor: Let me just check your vital signs. Your temperature is 36.9° Celsius, blood pressure is 165/109 millimeters of mercury, pulse is 88 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. I noticed you have difficulty opening your mouth and exhibit dysphonia. Is that related to your jaw pain?
Patient: Yes, it's been really hard to open my mouth, and it hurts when I try to force it.
Doctor: I see. I've conducted an oral exam and found no caries or abscesses, but the exam was limited due to your poor mouth opening. Your abdomen appears rigid and mildly distended, but not tender. I also noticed a healing laceration on the medial aspect of your right forearm, around 5 × 2 centimeters. Can you tell me how you got that wound?
Patient: I got it two weeks ago when I fell off a tractor at work and into muddy water.
Doctor: Did you see a doctor for the wound? And did you receive any treatment?
Patient: Yes, I saw a doctor in Mexico who gave me a topical medication, which I've been applying.
Doctor: And what about your immunization status? Did you receive tetanus prophylaxis for the wound or any childhood and adult vaccinations?
Patient: No, I didn't get tetanus prophylaxis for the wound, and as far as I can remember, I've never had any vaccinations.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. We have done some blood tests and a computed tomography scan of your head and neck, and the results are within normal limits. However, based on your history and symptoms, the likely diagnosis is tetanus. We will need to debride your wound and start the appropriate treatment.
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean for me, and what should I expect?
Doctor: We will clean your wound and remove any dead tissue to prevent the spread of the infection. We'll also provide you with medications to manage the symptoms and possibly a tetanus immunization. It's essential that you follow up with your primary care doctor and discuss updating your vaccination status.
Patient: Okay, thank you for the information and help. I'll be sure to follow up with my doctor.
soap_note:
S: The patient, a male with a history of hypertension (not on medication), presented with a chief complaint of jaw pain for the past three days, which has significantly impaired his ability to open his mouth and is associated with dysphonia. He also reports abdominal bloating. The patient denies any allergies and use of tobacco, alcohol, or drugs. He sustained a laceration on his right forearm two weeks ago, which was treated with topical medication in Mexico but did not receive tetanus prophylaxis.
O: Vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C, blood pressure at 165/109 mmHg, pulse 88 bpm, and respiratory rate 18 bpm. Physical examination revealed limited mouth opening due to pain, no oral caries or abscesses, a rigid and mildly distended abdomen without tenderness, and a healing laceration on the medial aspect of the right forearm measuring 5 × 2 cm. Blood tests and a CT scan of the head and neck were within normal limits.
A: The primary diagnosis is tetanus, considering the patient's unimmunized status, recent history of a potentially contaminated wound, and clinical symptoms of jaw stiffness and difficulty opening the mouth (trismus). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of jaw pain and abdominal symptoms, but these are less likely given the clinical context and findings.
P: The management plan includes surgical debridement of the forearm wound to prevent further infection spread. The patient will be started on tetanus immunoglobulin and a course of metronidazole to manage the infection. Tetanus vaccination will be administered, and pain management strategies will be discussed. The patient is advised to follow up with his primary care physician to update his vaccination status and manage his hypertension. Education regarding the importance of timely wound care and vaccination will be provided to prevent future incidents.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, patient. I understand that you've been diagnosed with MELAS, which is characterized by cytochrome c oxidase dysfunction. Can you tell me more about the symptoms you've been experiencing?
Patient: Yeah, I've suffered from severe mobility impairment and I'm wheelchair limited. I've also lost some of my hearing, have partial blindness, and have trouble swallowing.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Additionally, it seems you've been experiencing muscle weakness, asthenia, and exacerbated fatigue. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. The fatigue has been really tough to deal with.
Doctor: I can imagine. From a cardiovascular point of view, I see that your heart function has been reduced, which led to the necessity to implant a DDDR pacemaker. 
Patient: Yes, that's correct. They put the pacemaker in to help with my heart function.
Doctor: Our medical team has determined your clinical characteristics for an upcoming study. Before testing, we will need you to abstain from physical rehabilitation for 48 hours, caffeine for 12 hours, and food for 3 hours. Also, please avoid any drugs known to impact the response to the assessment procedures. This study will be carried out in accordance with the recommendations of the Declaration of Helsinki.
Patient: Okay, I understand. I'll make sure to follow those guidelines before the testing.
Doctor: Thank you. We'll be comparing your data to a control group of eight healthy, age- and sex-matched subjects who are recreationally active. Their demographic characteristics have been reported in our records.
Patient: I see. So what does the study involve? What will I be doing?
Doctor: You'll be visiting our laboratory on three separate occasions, each 24 hours apart. On the first visit, we'll conduct body composition testing (DXA) and clinical assessments. On the second visit, you'll familiarize yourself with the interpolated twitch and in vivo mitochondrial respiration capacity protocols. On the third visit, you'll complete an in vivo mitochondrial respiration capacity protocol utilizing a Near-infrared spectroscopy device (NIRS) on your right plantar-flexor muscles. 
Patient: Okay, that doesn't sound too bad.
Doctor: After a 60-minute recovery period, we'll then assess your maximal voluntary torque (MVC), electrically evoked resting twitch (EET), and maximal voluntary activation (VMA) of your right leg extensors (LE) muscles.
Patient: Alright, I'm ready to participate in the study. Thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. We appreciate your participation, and we hope that the findings from this study will help us better understand MELAS and how to better treat it in the future.
soap_note:
S: The patient reports severe mobility impairment, necessitating the use of a wheelchair, along with partial hearing loss, partial blindness, and dysphagia. The patient also experiences significant muscle weakness, asthenia, and exacerbated fatigue. A DDDR pacemaker was implanted to manage reduced heart function.
O: The patient is diagnosed with MELAS, characterized by cytochrome c oxidase dysfunction. Objective findings include the presence of a DDDR pacemaker to support cardiac function. The patient is scheduled for a study involving body composition testing (DXA), in vivo mitochondrial respiration capacity assessment using Near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) on the right plantar-flexor muscles, and measurements of maximal voluntary torque (MVC), electrically evoked resting twitch (EET), and maximal voluntary activation (VMA) of the right leg extensors (LE) muscles.
A: Primary diagnosis is MELAS, with complications including severe mobility impairment, sensory deficits (hearing and vision loss), dysphagia, muscle weakness, and cardiac dysfunction requiring pacemaker support. The upcoming study aims to further understand the mitochondrial dysfunction in MELAS and its impact on muscle and cardiac performance.
P: The patient is instructed to abstain from physical rehabilitation for 48 hours, caffeine for 12 hours, and food for 3 hours prior to testing, and to avoid drugs that could affect assessment outcomes. The study will involve three visits to the laboratory, with specific protocols outlined for each visit. The patient has agreed to comply with these requirements and participate in the study. Follow-up will include reviewing the study results to potentially adjust the treatment plan based on new insights gained about the disease pathology and response to interventions.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see you're a 35-year-old gravida four para four female who initially presented to urgent care with dysuria. How can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I was prescribed antibiotics for what they thought was a urinary tract infection, but my symptoms have gotten worse.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about your worsening symptoms?
